results.description:
This 2-Day comprehensive workshop explores visual storytelling with dynamic camera movement and skillful actor blocking.

Through extensive, daily hands-on exercises, participants will learn to visualize the scene, work with actors, strategize with storyboards, and evoke the essence of the script: DRAMA!

Participants will learn how to visualize, choose optimum camera positions, camera movement, and lens choices in relations with actor blocking.

Through this process, participants will understand how to convey tone, mood, and style, as well as give the film a distinct look that belongs to the director's unique vision.

WHEN: March 26-27 (Sat & Sun) 11am - 3pm
WHO: Narrative/Documentary Filmmakers
FEE: $425 Includes Studio and Equipment

LIMITED SEATING. Join us! Unleash Your Creativity!

results.description:
A warrior is sensitive to all aspects of phenomena—sight, smell, sound, feelings. He appreciates everything that goes on in his world as an artist does. His experience is full and extremely vivid. The rustling of leaves and sounds of raindrops on his coat are extremely loud. Because of his sensitivity, he can go deeper into his discipline… ” ~ Chogyam Trungpa

Self Exploration Through Sacred Warrior Boxing, Meditation and Plant Medicine

Cultivating their senses and internal strength, ancient warriors were sensitive to their surroundings and understood how to heal themselves using various practices to work within and increase power by attuning to nature.


Through these classes we will uncover strength and power that already exist through martial arts based movement, meditation and creative exploration. We’ll work to heighten our awareness through the senses and facilitate a deepening connection to nature in the city through plant medicine teachings and elemental meditations. Each week of movement, meditation and plant medicine work will correspond to an element inside and out with continued take home practices. The majority of the class is movement based. For all levels.

WEEKLY FOCUS:


March 26th
Earth
Introduction to the training program
Emphasis on Roots, foundation, stance, gathering and generating power from the ground up


April 2nd
Water
Flow, response, Intuition, Power through relaxation

April 9th
Fire
Intensity, passion, fuel, channeling primal energy


April 16th
Air
Attuning and responding to Sensation, Sound, Vibration, using visualization



Experience:
• Elemental meditations and martial arts practices

• Multi-dimensional exercises to tap into, and integrate our powerful primal energy we are often forced to suppress or misdirect

• Increased connection to nature in the city through learning about, and becoming aware of our many local medicinal plants

• Cultivation of the senses

• Creative exploration and stream-of-consciousness writing to move beyond the filters of the mind

• Take home mindfulness, movement and self care practices that relate to the exercises, plants and elements we’re working with

Limited to 15. Register Here to Reserve Space:  http://sacredwarrior.co/register/warriors-path-training-2016/

$25 is a special Spring Meetup rate for the first workshop only!

This course is a pre-requisite for the corresponding Warriors Path Plant Medicine and training intensives.
results.name: Warriors Path Training

results.description:
We are hosting a FinTech power brunch work with David Haber (Bond Street Co-Founder and CEO) & Alejandro Cremades (Onevest Co-Founder and Chairman). You’ll be able to able to chat with David & Alejandro about trends in NYC FinTech, learn what it takes to build a  successful company, participate in interactive startup challenges while pitching your best ideas, and build connections with other young go-getters eager for opportunities, all while enjoying a fireside setting with a delicious seasonal brunch from our friends at 
Ox Verte.  To officially register and purchase tickets you must use this link to  the event here.

Pleased to offer 20% off the event with code "Byte"

About the speakers 

David Haber is the cofounder & CEO of Bond Street, a startup focused on transforming small business lending through technology, data and design. Its impressive software can make a loan decision in 24-48 hours. Bond Street raised a Series A round of $110 million from investment bank Jefferies, Spark Capital, and founders of Momofuku and Airbnb.

David was most recently an investor at Spark Capital, where he focused on marketplace and financial services investments. Prior, David co-founded Locus Analytics, a startup asset management business. David was recently recognized on the Forbes 30 Under 30 list.

Alejandro Cremades is the cofounder & Executive Chairman of Onevest, which provides technology products to connect founders, investors, advisors and influencers in the entrepreneurship community. Onevest operates 1000 Angels (the world's largest digital-first, invitation-only investor network) & CoFoundersLab(the leading matchmaking service for founders).

Alejandro guest lectures at NYU Stern School of Business and The Wharton Business School. He has been included in the Top 30 Under 30 lists of Vanity Fair, Entrepreneur Magazine, and GQ. Most recently, Alejandro is the author of The Art of Startup Fundraising.  

You can get tickets to the event here. YOU MUST USE THIS LINK TO PURCHASE A TICKET AND OFFICIALLY REGISTER

About Byte Academy:  Byte Academy is an industry-focused coding bootcamp in the heart of Manhattan offering full and part-time programs emphasizing Python programming language. Programs include: fullstack Python development, FinTech (financial technology), Data Science and MedTech (medical technology). Byte Academy is the first coding camp in New York City to offer a full-time Python program and is the only in the world to teach FinTech. The school has small classes, career services and placement including access to top industry professionals and events. Byte Academy offers comprehensive financial aid and all women receive a $2,000 off tuition upon acceptance to the program. Through Byte Academy's Tuition-Deferral Program, qualified applicants pay $0 until they find a job. Byte Academy is now accepting applications for its Part-Time Fullstack Python, FinTech and Data Science Classes!

Follow Byte Academy: @byteacademyco (twitter) @byteacademy (facebook & instagram)
results.name: FinTech Power Brunch w/Bond Street CEO & OneVest Chairman

group.name: Byte Academy: FinTech, Data Science, Python Coding Bootcamp

results.description:
Come join us and cook at the outdoor wood-fired oven at the Old Stone House!

Have children? Don't know how to cook or don't have time to prepare something? Join us for "Build Your Own Pizzas" at Noon!

We provide the dough and a variety of fresh toppings... you provide the fun!  Come and assemble your own personal pizza, and we'll help you bake it in a 900-degree wood-fired brick oven.


Then at 1pm, the oven will be open for everyone to cook their own dishes!

We'll meet at the stone oven next to the Old Stone House. Firing the oven will start around 9am, and we'll start baking at noon. For details of time and temperature, check out our FAQ.


We'll be outside the entire time, so be sure to dress warmly and wear multiple layers.

Open Baking Day, and Build Your Own Pizzas, are free and open to the public!

If you enjoy this event, please do consider donating $5 (or more if you can) to the Old Stone House to help pay for firewood. Or, contribute to the oven rebuilding project fundraiser on Indiegogo, and get some great perks!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the yard inside the fence, in front of the oven, next to the Old Stone House and J.J.Byrne Playground.
results.name: Open Baking Day at the Old Stone House

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Learn & Sweat Bhangra sessions are for you 

- if you want start your weekend with a bang

- if you love to sweat it out to heart pumping music

- if you think fitness doesn't mean lifting weights

- if you want to learn and groove to energetic Bhangra while burning serious cals.

The class begins with a warm up, high energy and high fun, this Bhangra class combines the strong, festive moves of traditional Bhangra dance with a follow-me fitness-class style. 

Each week participants also have the opportunity to learn a more in-depth piece of Bhangra choreography to a popular dance floor hit. 

If you love Bhangra music and you’re looking for a fun, unique way to keep fit, join us to sweat it out while partying to the beats.

No previous dance experience is necessary - just bring in your smile! Our Instructors are professional, friendly, and open minded. So come on in and let swag emerge!

Wear comfortable clothes and shoes.

The drop-in price is $20 and can be paid here on meetup, or head over to our website www.nycbhangra.com/nycbhangra/signup for other options to pay.

Checkout our other BEGINNER BHANGRA classes too!
results.name: Learn & Sweat BHANGRA

results.description:
Here's a video from our last performance; "Santa Baby"


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Eq5zNQPuFw

This Season we are playing The Beatles!

We have done Classic Rock, The Rolling Stones, Reggae, Motown, Summer Songs, Fleetwood Mac, Funk and Christmas ensembles, The Beatles is certainly due in our selection!

Acoustic guitars, bass and ukeleles welcome. If electric bring a portable amp:)


This ensemble welcomes ALL LEVELS, so pick your part and let's play! 

To join:

• RSVP before you attend the session.

• Choose your guitar part from TAB>MORE>FILES download/print and bring it to practice to follow. (check by 12/30) 

• Bring acoustic guitar or electric with a portable amp. 

• Have an amazing time!

Practice days are:

Every Saturday 12-2pm starting January 9th til April 23rd, the day before the performance, 16 practice sessions.

Season Pass

You can purchase the Season Pass (16 sessions at discount + $30 show fee) for $380  (you save $50 on practice sessions)

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=MWF56937BM6Q8


Show Day is Sunday, May 1st at 2pm

The show will be at Arlene's Grocery in the East Village April 24th at 1pm(soundcheck) and doors at 2pm. Arlene's is an awesome show venue with professional stage, sound and lights, everyone will be miked or amplified. If you are coming to rehearsal with a portable amp you should also bring it to the venue.

We will have a drummer and a singer TBA.

There will be tickets for this show, they can be purchase before hand at $5 or at the door for $10.

There is a show fee of $30 for each ensemble member that will go toward venue, sound engineer and hired musicians costs.

Arlene's Grocery is strictly 21+ and no children will be allowed at the show even if they are accompanied by the parent, I'm sorry:( :(

There are two bars on site and lots of food spots and great restaurants in the area for before or after the show.

All you need is love and some Beatles!

Check out our website at http://edelage.wix.com/edge

results.description:
*THERE IS A MANDATORY $15 MINIMUM PURCHASE OF FOOD OR DRINK AT THIS EVENT*

*

Saturday will allow us more time to play!  Let's grab a bite to eat, maybe some drinks, and play some games! Yes, there are games you may never have heard of ... Splendor, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Saboteur, Imperial Settlers, Suburbia and many many more!! Not to worry! People who bring the games will teach you how to play.  If you have a game you want to play, bring it along! 


We will get there around noon and will stay to around 6 - 7 p.m.!!  But, if you can't get there until later or need to leave earlier, no problem.  As you can see, we'll be there for several hours.   Don't want to eat there?  No problem, you can order some drinks.  Just keep in mind ... each attendee is required to purchase at least $15 of food or drinks.

If anyone has a specific game they wish to play,  feel free to ask.  And again, if you want to bring one of your own games, that's cool too!  As a matter of fact, it's encouraged!  ;-)

This event is cross-posted to multiple Meetup groups as seen here (scroll to the bottom to see attendees) + over 1,400 RSVP'd via Facebook. This is going to an AMAZING event!! 

Check out the pics from the last event. We had the best time ever!! 

Welcome to the happiest day party in New York City! The Festival of Colors celebrates the coming of spring, the joy of friendship, and equality for all. This Indian Festival happens every year, not only in India but throughout the world. Join us on March 19th or March 26th. This is a day event and all nationalities and ethnicities are encouraged to participate!

Make sure to wear white because this party gets colorful. The colored powders used in Holi represent happiness, love, and the freedom to live vibrantly. Take the opportunity to cover yourself and your friends in colorful powders and dance your heart out. Enjoy musical performances, delicious food, and an afternoon of messy, color fun! 

GET YOUR TICKETS HERE: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/holi-in-the-city-color-party-saturday-march-26th-stage48-nyc-tickets-20438819058?aff=HOLI326&afu=133842352783

Another ridiculously awesome event brought to you by Date Walking - The Easiest Way to Meet Someone Special

results.description:
For two weeks,  the clothing and accessories at Macy's won't be the only colorful items on display by the iconic department store. Outside in Broadway Plaza beautifully bright floral arrangements will announce this year's Macy's Flower Show.

Join Macy's for a stunning celebration of our country’s vast and varied landscapes—from purple mountain majesties and across the wilderness! We’ll tell the story through fabulous flora indigenous to each of our nation’s regions to celebrate iconic destinations from sea to shining sea!

***Admission to the Flower Show is FREE.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

***SUNGLASS HUT - 1313 Broadway & 34th Street (212)[masked]


We are meeting in front of the Sunglass Hut on the the corner of Macy's Herald Square.  Macy's is too crowded to meet there.  If it is cold or raining you can go inside the Sunglass Hut and wait for everyone to arrive.  Please try to be on time!


*A meetup fee of $2.00 will be collected here so please have it ready when you arrive.  Thank you.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

LUNCH (optional)


After the show, we will have lunch at Brendan's on 35th St (bet 5th & 6</a><a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=151+W+34th+St%2C+New+York%2C+NY%2C+US">th Ave) where we have been several times before, including our holiday party a few years ago.  Prices are moderate and you can have lunch ($9 - $16) or a fixed-price brunch including a drink ($18).  If you prefer to eat somewhere else or grab a quick bite, like pizza, you are free to do that.

*** If you are going please bring SMALL BILLS (1's, 5's, 10's) and a $20 bill to help facilitate payment.  Thank you.

----------------------------------------------------------------

***PLEASE ONLY REPLY YES IF YOU ARE SURE YOU CAN ATTEND SINCE I AM LIMITING THE NUMBER OF MEMBERS GOING.  Of course, if a true emergency arises, I will understand.


------------------------------------------------------------------

Subway (mta.info/weekender - please check for times and service advisories the day/night before)

Take R train to 34th St/Herald Square

Take F/D train to 34th St/Herald Square

Take C/E train to 34th St/Penn Station


Meetup Fee: $2.00 to help defray the cost of maintaining the group will be collected at the Sunglass Hut.  EXACT CHANGE PLEASE.


Perfume Allergy: Please refrain from wearing perfume. Thanks for understanding.

<a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?q=151%20W%2034th%20St%2C%20New%20York%2C%20NY"></a>

This is an opportunity for you to get your jam on!

This meetup focuses on giving members opportunities to solo, play off each other, experiment with different percussion sounds, and rhythm games.

I bring a few drums and percussion instruments, but I advise you to bring your own if have. 'Veteran' members, please bring a small instrument for someone to play.

I also suggest you bring:

-Water and/or food to share
-Small folding stool or blanket to sit on
-A song and/or rhythm to share

Every meetup is also an opportunity for YOU to faciliate!!! Please let me know before we start if you are interested in facilitating.

Let's play well TOGETHER!!!

results.description:
To take this course, you must first attend the free introductory webinar, Introduction to Nurturing Nature:  Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earths and read the Nurture Nature Guide, both of which are free. The Introductory webinar occurs Saturday, March 19th, at 12 p.m. EDT.  In this course on Emotional Intelligence we go into much greater depth than the introductory webinar, so that you grow your capacity to nurture and to nature.  This two part webinar will concentrate on only one of the five intelligences, Emotional Intelligence.  During our time together you will have the chance to connect to your body, and find ways to nurture yourself through self-empathy and other tools of compassionate and nonviolent communication.  

To register for the introductory webinar, go here:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/introduction-to-nurturing-nature-yours-ours-theirs-the-earths-tickets-22062826508?aff=affiliate1

The first two webinars on Emotional Intelligence are available on March 26th and April 2nd, both at 12 p.m. EDT.  The $25 pays for both webinars.   Only pay for the first webinar on March 26th and we will send you the information to join up with the second webinar on April 2nd, free of charge.  Additional modules become available in July 2016.

Once you register for this two part webinar we will send you the Nurture Nature Guide as well as information on how to link to the online webinar experience. You will need a computer with internet access, or a mobile phone with internet access.  You can also join by direct phone, but you will not be able to see the visuals, which we can send to you as a separate file.

To register for the two webinars on Emotional Intelligence go here:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/nurturing-nature-for-life-emotional-intelligence-tickets-22076954766

Come join us and get painted in reds, yellows, greens, pinks.... and enjoy the Indian Festival of colors in style with food, drinks, and the amazing beats of DJ Ashu Rai & Dholi Mohit. Dance performances by Bollywood Touch

This event is 21+

Join us in a unique celebration of Women's History Month with a second tour to visit some very special locations in Manhattan associated with individual women and social movements that have had a lasting impact on New York City, the U.S. and the world!  Note this is a completely different route than the March  12 Tour.


We Visit:  A bit of Chelsea, Greenwich Village, East Village and Gramercy Neighborhoods

This is two tours in one! Visit some of New York's most fascinating neighborhoods as we take in some unique and very important sites and buildings. Stops include: Ottendorfer Library and Polyclinic Hospital (honoring German immigrant Anna Ottendorfer who started the first free lending library and a health clinic serving poorer immigrants); Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Building; (honoring the successful struggle for better working conditions in factories); New York Studio School (honoring visionary champions of American art Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney and Julianna Force); the homes of Eleanor Roosevelt, Emma Lazarus, Bella Abzug, Dorothy Day and Emma Goldman; Margaret Sanger's pioneering Manhattan Clinic; and the United Charities Building (which housed influential women's groups and shaped the U.S. Government's role in addressing human needs). 

Cheers,

Hank

[masked]

[masked]
results.name: Special walking Tour In Celebration of Women's History Month

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Open Play for Advanced Beginners and Intermediate Players.

Our game starts promptly at 11:30am.  You are welcome to come slightly earlier to change and warm up.

We can accommodate 3 teams, 8 players per team max (double rotation). Rally scoring. Game to 15 when it's 3 teams, Game to 25 when it's 2 teams. 

IMPORTANT - Skill Level Required for our Open Play

Know how to rotate on the court, serve, pass, set, spike and block. Know how to hold your position on the court during defense and offense.  This is meant for players that have experience playing.

Rules will be enforced to protect all players from safety and fun.

Recreational players and beginners can practice on the side or come watch for FREE. We also run a skills clinic to improve your game. Please ask!

If you will be attending for the first time, please check in with me for a quick 3 min assessment. 

Thanks and hope to see you on the court!

May
results.name: Volleyball Open Play

venue.address_1: Entrances on 51st and 52nd St. between Fifth and Madison Aves.
venue.name: Onassis Cultural Center atrium (main floor near tables). I'll be wearing a red cap.

results.description:
Starting this weekend, the Onassis Cultural Center's beautiful underground space will present its first exhibition in nearly four years: Gods and Mortals at Olympus: Ancient Dion, City of Zeus. A trove of artifacts unearthed in the past 40 years will bring to life the art, culture, and religion of this little-known city. In addition, we will visit the annual Macy's flower show, the Fashion Institute of Technology's museum, a fabulous gem store, the latest exhibitions at Grand Central and the NY Public Library, plus churches, chapels, waterfalls, and pocket parks, where we'll eat lunch (details below). 

PLEASE READ THESE DETAILS, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED:

DISTANCE: About 2 miles

PACE: Moderate (3 blocks in 4 minutes), NOT SLOW. Stragglers will prevent the group from reaching all our destinations. 

COST: $2, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee. (Everything else is free.)

LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll eat in a lovely pocket park before 2 PM. 

TRANSPORTATION: #6 train to 51st Street and Lexington Avenue; E train to 5th Avenue/53rd Street; or B, D, or F train to 47-50 Street/Rockefeller Center at 6th Avenue. For details, consult mta.tripplanner.org and/or a subway map, since the online site does not always list the ideal routes. 

WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient. The list will shrink or disappear by the morning of the walk, due to cancellations and no-shows, especially at the last minute. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up. And don't worry about huge crowds--the number who actually show up is generally 35 to 55, no matter how many are signed up or waiting.

group.name: The New York International Happy Hour

results.description:
Francisco will be hosting another bar crawl/run!

Where are we meeting?

We are meeting at the Roosevelt Ave subway station at 12h30.

Not a runner?


No problem. You can walk the course.


You don't drink alcohol?


You can still join. You can be the designated sober runner. However you might not enjoy hanging out with a bunch of tipsy runners.

Can I join you later?


Yes you can join us later. I will post my number in the comments section before the run and you can texts me to find us. The best way though is to download Glympse which is an app that will help you track us. I will also have someone update the comments section on the location as we hit each pub.

How long does this take?


Usually about 6 to 7 hours. We stop each bar about 45 minutes to an hour. This way we have time to drink and get some food if the pub has food.

Route:

Leg 1:

Roosevelt Ave to The Dog and Duck (1.4 miles)

West on Roosevelt Ave then right on Skillman. Dog and Duck

45-20 Skillman Ave

Leg 2:

Dog and Duck to Monika's Cafe Bar (1.1 miles)

West on Skillman then right on 43rd St then left on 34th Ave. Monika's Cafe Bar

[masked]th St

Leg 3:

Monika's Cafe to Sweet Afton (0.6 miles)

North on 36th St for 3 blocks then left on 30th Ave.

Leg 4:

Sweet Afton to Snowdonia (0.8 miles)

East on 30th Ave then left on 32nd St

Snowdonia

[masked]nd St

Leg 5:

Snowdonia to LIC Bar (1.7 miles)

South on 32nd St until you hit Northern Blvd. Then run on Northern Blvd to Jackson Ave then right on 46th Ave. The bar is on 46th ave and Vernon Blvd.

LIC Bar

45-58 Vernon Blvd

Leg 6:

LIC Bar to t.b.d. Brooklyn (1.3 miles)

224 Franklin St

South on Vernon Blvd then left on 49th St. Run on the Pulaski Bridge then right on Eagle and left on Franklin St.


Link to google maps route

results.description:
Our last Amazing Scavenger Brooklyn Museum Hunt was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team or an individual and we will put you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Mar-26-2016_at_1230PM

Prepay Only Event. No tickets sold at door. 

What to expect:  

• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*Tickets $35-$40 depending upon when you purchase - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Mar-26-2016_at_1230PM

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers. 

What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest. You can download that before you come.

What if it rains/snows? No problem, the scavenger hunt is all indoors.

Why RSVP says +25? Multiple Meetup groups are organizing this event so don't just go by the RSVPs here. There will be up to 50 members attending and this will sell out! 

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Mar-26-2016_at_1230PM
results.name: The Amazing Brooklyn Museum Scavenger Hunt (includes entry to Museum)PREPAY ONLY

results.description:
Do you have regrets about a relationship with a family member? This round table discussion will focus on the topic of regret in relationship to family. Over an hour or so, we will be sharing our stories and mapping the anatomy of this emotion, pausing on understanding how regret feels, rather than necessarily how to overcome it. 


The group and discussions are gently facilitated by a design consultancy specializing in social and emotional well-being, mattermindstudio.com. 

*We'll be serving light refreshments, but feel free to bring your own lunch!

*This group nor the conversations are facilitated by licensed mental health professionals.
results.name: Round Table: Regret + Family

results.description:
Our last Amazing Scavenger Brooklyn Museum Hunt was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team or an individual and we will put you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Mar-26-2016_at_1230PM

Prepay Only Event. No tickets sold at door. 

What to expect:  

• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul
results.name: Soccer Saturday -@west 134th Street Field - 12:45pm

venue.address_1: In Front of CVS by the Massapequa LIRR Station
venue.name: Massapequa Preserve

results.description:
This Hike is a Sierra Club Event.

Hike @ Massapequa Preserve

5+ Miles Flat Terrain around 3 hours

THEN 

AFTERPARTY @ MILLER's Ale House !!!

Directions:

EASILY ACCESSIBLE VIA LIRR

Take LIRR from Penn Stn or Atlantic Terminal to Massapequa Train Station!

(Not Massapequa Park Train station)

Sunrise Hwy to Broadway, Massapequa (a traffic light and a diner are on the corner). Go NORTH under the RR trestle. At the light, turn immediately right. Look for CVS.

Park @ LIRR Station!

HIKE around a Beautiful Preserve!

Warmer Weather ==> Awesome Hiking Time!

PLUS ... a Healthy - Positive - Afternoon

Talk, Network, Mingle! 
Feel positive, Feel Free and good about yourself! 
Enjoy the breeze, the calmness!

Multi-Meetup Combined Event

Please Don't Forget the Positive MOOD

AND YOUR CAMERA

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

IMPORTANT ... IMPORTANT ... IMPORTANT !!!

1. Bring water, Bananas or nuts or Granola Bars, Bug Repellent & Sunblock.

2. ALWAYS check meetup page before departing ANY event for any last minute updates. 

3. Never wear NEW shoes on a Hike. Always break them in!

4. No GUESTS: Everyone is welcome to attend, they just need to signup individually. We need to ensure everyone reads the ENTIRE description PRIOR to attending so they are aware of the type of event they are signing up for. 

5. Kids are welcome. Hikes are a healthy and a family bonding experience.

6. Please refrain from posting weather related comments on the meetup site. No one logs on to meetup to check weather.

7. Please read meetup description IN ITS ENTIRETY before posting a COMMENT. Meetup Comments must ONLY be used for important questions AFFECTING EVERYONE.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is an event organized for our friends to get together and socialize. We are not professional hikers or professional organizers. You are welcome to join us but before you attend you must familiarize yourself with the risks associated with this type of activity.

Liability Waiver

Hiking or outdoor activities have inherent risks. Your participation in our hikes or other events could be dangerous and can result in serious injury, medical emergency, even death. It is your responsibility to learn the trails and to follow the group so you do not get detached from the group. Make yourself aware of your surroundings and trail conditions at all times. You agree to participate in these events completely at your own risk and to take full responsibility for your own safety and well being, including those of your guests. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Co-Organizer, Assistant Organizers, Event Organizer, Event Hosts, Hike Leader or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. Your attendance at the event signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
results.how_to_find_us: meet in front of CVS at Massapequa LIRR Station
results.name: Hike Massapequa Preserve - Afterparty @ Miller's Ale House!!!

On the southern shores of the Moonsea, the residents of Mulmaster have eked out a living where others would likely have given up long ago—in a bleak city where corruption is rampant and the Church of Bane holds sway.

Join both veteran and new players of D&D for this Adventures league event.

results.description:
RSVP'S ARE CLOSED

PLEASE READ THE DESCRIPTION OF THIS EVENT CAREFULLY. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS SERIOUSLY AND I EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO.

Join me and AMC club members who do not have to RSVP on a fast paced, fun hike of about 7 miles. (Don’t ask me how I figured out the mileage). I try to do this at least once a year.

MEETING DETAILS WILL BE  SENT OUT BY E-MAIL TO ALL THOSE WHO RSVP'D ON THURSDAY EVENING MARCH 24, 2016 BY 9:00 P.M.

We’ll start out visiting a few of the larger art galleries in the Lower East Side-it’ll be fast and furious- and then we’ll walk over the Bridge to Williamsburg, Brooklyn. In hipster Williamsburg, a world onto itself where no one over 30 years old is allowed to live according to law, we’ll spend most of the time walking along the Waterfront, visit a State Park and hopefully the Brooklyn Bowl. (2013's Academy Award winning short film, “Curfew” by Shawn Christensen, was filmed at the Bowl and can be inexpensively downloaded. You want the short not the full length version shown in the movies. It is truly great.). There will definitely be many surprises along the way. We will meet BEFORE 1:00 P.M. Be ready to go. WE LEAVE ON TIME. NO FOOD STOPS.

Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. Since this event will be posted as a last minute hike to AMC Club members, there is NO need for AMC Club members to RSVP for this-UNLESS –you don’t get last minute e-mails (Contact me –don’t post a comment-if you are a dues paying member a few days before the hike and I’ll tell you how to get these e-mails). Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members. (I am going to give preference to those who have attended hikes I have led in the past.). 

Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate because space is limited. If you have been a NO SHOW on any of the previous AMC Meetup events that I have led or you abuse the RSVP process-see your Attendance History- please do not sign up for this event. Unfortunately your ship has sailed. 

I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. You have more than enough information to do this once you get the meeting details. No offense, but I don’t need to know-and probably neither does anyone else- what you are doing that day if you can’t make it or what you think the weather will be. AFTER the event, post as many comments and photos as you like.

If the weather forecast is really bad, see Accuweather like I do, I will post a notice Saturday morning on the day of the hike by 10:00 A.M. If there is no notice, we go. We will finish around 5:30 P.M near a subway station.
results.name: Lower  East Side/Williamsburg Expedition and Mini Gallery Hop

group.name: Appalachian Mountain Club New York-North Jersey

results.description:
Join us for our March edition of GUY GALLERY WALK: a tour of the BEST ART SHOWS in the Chelsea Gallery District- 


1ST STOP: PAUL KASMIN GALLERY [masked]th Ave @ 27th St) presents: JAMES NARES,  11 PORTRAITS

Using a camera specifically developed by Fastec Imaging to have cinematic applications as well as the technical and scientific for which they are best known, against a simple backdrop allowing the viewer to focus entirely on the subject.


Filmed at several hundred frames per second, each video ranges between eleven and thirty-five minutes in length and is displayed on close to life-sized, ultra-high definition monitors that render minute details with infinite precision and reveal a boundless complexity of thoughts, emotions, and movement. By engaging the subject with the lens, Nares deepens the viewers sense of connection with the work, and offers an opportunity to observe the sitter in a way that may owe more to painting than still photography.  “A still photograph is a lie,” says the artist. “People are not merely a single moment in time.”

2ND STOP: JAMES COHAN GALLERY (533 W 26TH  ST) presents: OMER FAST, 3 FILMS

New York premiere of three recent films, 5,000 Feet is the Best (2011), Continuity (2012), and Spring (2016). The exhibition, the artist’s first at James Cohan


In his work as a filmmaker, Omer Fast defines a new relationship between reality and fiction. He is interested in exploring the construction of narratives, in particular how stories change when told from different perspectives. The works in the exhibition each examine the shifting boundaries of modern conflict through the personal stories of those involved. Fast borrows from traditions of documentary, dramatization and fantasy, manipulating time through the use of repetition, looping, and reenactment to create new and complex structures. All three works use human emotions as stand-ins for the larger socio-political reality of contemporary warfare.

3RD STOP:  MITCHELL-INNES & NASH (534 W 26TH ST) PRESENTS: SARAH BRAMAN, YOU ARE EVERYTHING

Braman is known for her large-scale sculptures in which parts of scrapyard vehicles and old furniture are combined with translucent volumes of color and light.  The artist’s distinctive color palette of rich pinks, blues and purples permeates the exhibition, from spray paint on found objects and hand-dyed fabric to the expansive colors of the glass forms. 


For her most recent series, Braman uses scavenged objects from domestic life, such as discarded bunk bed, a truck cap, assorted furniture, as a starting point. Their visible wear-and-tear speaks to the passage of time and recalls the everyday struggles and joys to which these objects bore witness. Braman turns the utility of these objects on their head, destabilizing the notions of home and family.

In contrast, the glass forms to which these objects are attached appear otherworldly. Placed at off-kilter angles throughout the exhibition space, the sunset colored blocks generate a light and shadow that quietly uproot these broken down memorials.

4th STOP: ROBERT MILLER GALLERY (524 W 26TH ST) PRESENTS: PATTI SMITH, EIGHTEEN STATIONS

Eighteen Stations revolves around the world of M Train, Smith’s bestselling book released in 2015. M Train chronicles, as Smith describes, “a roadmap to my life,” as told from the seats of the cafés and dwellings she has worked from globally. Reflecting the themes and sensibility of the book, Eighteen Stations is a meditation on the act of artistic creation. It features the artist’s illustrative photographs that accompany the book’s pages, along with works by Smith that speak to art and literature’s potential to offer hope and consolation. The artist will be reading from M Train at the Gallery throughout the run of the exhibition.


5TH STOP: DRISCOLL BABCOCK (525 w 25TH ST) PRESENTS: LOST GENERATION, PAINTINGS

works done between[masked], selection of American works hallmarking the decade of the 1920’s when the United States and Europe were reeling in the aftermath of World War I. Gertrude Stein credited her auto mechanic with the “Lost Generation” moniker and Ernest Hemingway made it stick in The Sun Also Rises. While generally associated with writers, the “Lost Generation” was all encompassing—Americans who came of age during the First World War—some of whom served in the war, all of whom were subject to its upheaval.

6TH STOP: PACE GALLLERY (510 W 25TH ST) PRESENTS: QIU XIAOFEI, DOUBLE PENDULUM

Using acrylic paint, Qiu appropriates palette knives, spray guns, brushes and other implements in an improvisational manner; giving in to and resisting the resulting sprays, drips and even the creation of forms. The art, which leans towards abstraction, explores the potential of form plus colour, and thus expresses what the artist calls ‘a social subconscious’.

‘There has been a kind of distant coolness in Chinese art, even when it refers to the West in style,’ says Arne Glimcher, chairman of Pace Gallery in New York. ‘Qiu Xiaofei’s painting is unique in China and spearheads a new generation of Chinese abstraction. Although his personal references are encapsulated in expressionistic color and enigmatic symbols, they are uniquely Chinese.

7TH STOP: YOSSI MILO (245 W 10TH AVE) PRESENT: CHRIS McCAW, DIRECT POSITIVE

Chris McCaw builds his own large-format cameras and outfits them with powerful lenses typically used for military surveillance and aerial reconnaissance. Instead of film, McCaw inserts expired fiber-based gelatin silver photo paper directly into the camera. Pointing the lens at the sun, McCaw makes recordings ranging from thirty seconds to as long as 36 hours. The sun, intensified by the lens, scorches its path across the paper while creating a solarized image of the landscape or seascape below – a “direct positive” image made in-camera, without an intervening negative. These burned lines and holes are tangible traces of the act of making each photograph: marking time, recording location, mapping weather conditions and channeling light.


8TH STOP: GLADSTONE (515 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: T.J. WILCOX, EQUIVALENTS

The show will present new film installations and lenticular photographic lightboxes, exploring the movement and mutation of cloudscapes as compelling abstracted narratives.


In this installation, Wilcox leads viewers to look upward to the ceiling, an often-overlooked surface within the gallery space. Suggestive of the natural world beyond the enclosed built environment and beyond human stature, the assembled projections offer a view of the extraordinary, unpredictable, and the everyday experience of gazing upward at the sky. The artist has produced sculptures that hang from the ceiling at a single point, comprising an arrangement of steel, Plexiglas and projected video. These hanging sculptures suspend in balance a group of projection screens arranged to float overhead like a cluster of abstracted clouds. The screens are made of a new material that allows rear-projected video to brightly appear in high resolution in any light condition. Wilcox’s structures engender awe for the enormity and phenomena of the natural world that often goes unnoticed; non-linear narratives concerning the act of looking upward interspersed in the films additionally offer further reflection on the world above our heads.

9TH STOP: ANDREA ROSEN (525 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: LIZZIE  FITCH AND RYAN TRECARTIN, INSTALLATIONS

Furthering their notion of “sculptural theaters”—installations built as containers for specific movies, whose architectural, audiovisual, and sculptural elements expand onscreen content into environmental panoramas—the artists have transformed Andrea Rosen Gallery into a network of halls and chambers that plot a path for visitors through a sequence of new movies and ambient spaces. 


The thematic language of these enclosures is lifted from lakeside Americana—nature as retreat. One room is distinguished from a placeless labyrinth by the railing of a pontoon boat that snakes around its perimeter; another is floored with pine 2x4s resembling a dock. The movie looped in this room is projected beyond the edge of the planks, above a shallow drop into a carpeted void simulating water. Elsewhere, seating is carved from foam, tromp l’oeil boulders. The entire space is bound together by an atmospheric composition of nature sounds largely produced by an online sound generator, instilling a kind of numbed, placid continuity.

These rustic cues are a departure from generically slick, suburban merchandise shopped from international retailers, the likes of which the artists are best known for casting as furnishings for their installations. But the great outdoors is the jurisdiction of only another department in the same type of store, whose all-purpose ubiquity reflects the comfort cravings of the American psyche.

10TH STOP: FREDERICKS & FREISER (536 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: MARK THOMAS GIBSON,  SOME MONSTERS LOOM LARGE

11TH STOP: JACK SHAINMAN (524 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: BARKLEY L HENDRICKS, NEW WORKS


his most political to date. Steeped in pop culture and balanced with exquisite detail, the cast of characters in Hendricks’ work inhabits an unconventional realism united by painterly mastery.Hendricks culls subjects for his hagiographic portraits from sartorially minded friends and acquaintances he has encountered around the world, including travels to Jamaica, his hometown of Philadelphia, and Connecticut where Hendricks now lives and works. 


12TH STOP: SIKKEMA JENKINS (530 W 22ND ST) PRESENTS: KEIICHI TANAAMI, VISIBLE DARKNESS, INVISIBLE DARKNESS

Tanaami came of age in post-war Japan and began his career in advertising. Finding the work artistically unfulfilling, he ventured into the burgeoning 1960s Japanese art scene and began making collages and films influenced by American mass culture, B movies, and a trip to New York where he visited Warhol’s factory. He befriended artists from the Japanese anti-art movement Neo Dada Organizers while they were making their groundbreaking work. Like other Pop artists he was also inspired by eroticism, an impulse that eventually led him to become an editor of Playboy Japan in 1975. Reflected in the new paintings featured in the exhibition is Tanaami’s engagement with his contemporary artistic environment and continued reimagining of traditional Japanese iconography. Cherry blossoms, Guzei bridges and Buddha figures are featured alongside roosters and tigers, inspired by the work of Ito Jakachu, an 18th century scroll painter.Tanaami, now in his 80s, is making his largest and most technically ambitious work to date. Unique to his practice in terms of scale, the new paintings are emblematic ofTanaami’s evolving career and myriad international influences.

13TH STOP: PAULA COOPER GALLERY (521 W 21ST) PRESENTS: JENNIFER BARTLETT

Known for monumental and conceptual multi-panel works composed of programmatic grids, Jennifer Bartlett negotiates an intersection between precise geometry and lyrical figuration. In the five diptychs on view, she expands her representational painting to engage the structural underpinnings of her natural surroundings. Houses, shorelines and marshes near her home in Amagansett or foliage, flowers and landscaped paths from her Brooklyn garden occupy her canvases. Based on Bartlett’s original photographs, her compositions diverge to create a delicate discord within each diptych; the pairs of square panels juxtapose two images of the same scene but with shifting perspective, slight distortions of scale or altered perceptions. In Rose [masked]), the two compositions seem to simply contrast in spatial proximity, though further examination reveals a complex abstraction. As Bartlett describes: “It’s a little like a stereopticon, only off-kilter.”


Painting with graining brushes, Bartlett builds layer upon layer to weave an expressionistic grid, a dense fabric rich with tactile complexity. Often used for decorative painting, a graining brush’s multiple bristles groups are arranged equidistantly so that the painted gesture leaves a trail of parallel lines.

14TH STOP: GLADSTONE GALLERY (530 W 21ST) PRESENTS: PHILLIPE PARRENO, IF THIS THEN ELSE

a time based-exhibition and a conditional construct. Scripted events are automated by command lines executed within a computer: if a light goes off, then a film is screened and the temperature in the room changes; if the film finishes screening, then the lights are turned on…


Activities within the bioreactor control the overall scenario of the exhibition, although the computer writes and repeats the scripts with some variation. Inside the bioreactor, the microorganisms anticipate the rhythms, “predictable” qualities, and dramaturgy of the exhibition environment. In return, the organisms can alter the conditions within the bioreactor and in the exhibition space outside of its habitat, revealing a basic relationship between time and living matter. When the microorganisms inside the bioreactor detect time-related variations, they can mutate or evolve in anticipation of future variations. Alternatively, they can remain passive and follow the transformations by adjusting their inner molecular clocks.

15TH STOP: DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (525 W 19TH ST) PRESENTS, KARLA BLACK, NEW SCULPTURES

sculptures made specifically for the space and completed on site.


Combining traditional artistic materials such as chalk, paper, paint, and plaster with everyday items including eye shadow, earth, ribbon, toilet paper, and cotton wool, Black’s works are at once elaborate and simple, expressive and restrained. They challenge their own medium by being “almost” or “only just” objects with a close affinity to painting, performance art, and installation. As the artist notes, the “most important thing about the work is that it prioritizes material experience over language as a way to learn about and understand the world.”

16TH STOP: MICHAEL ROSENDFELD [masked]TH AVE @ 19TH ST) PRESENTS: THEODORE ROSZAK, PROPULSIVE TRANSFIGURATION, A STUDY OF DRAWINGS[masked]

Known more as a sculptor, with over 60 drawings on display,  these drawings reveal his capacious intellect and expansive range of interests. The title of the exhibition alludes to Roszak’s fascination with the dynamics of metamorphosis—the transformative energies of the natural, organic world as well as the potential of technology and industry to alter the world, for better and for worse. A voracious consumer of ideas, Roszak found inspiration for his prolific body of work in a variety of sources. These included: the design and engineering innovation of streamlining that Norman Bel Geddes addressed in Horizons; the psychoanalytic theories of Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, and Otto Rank; French purism; atomic energy; aeronautics and space exploration; and the art and culture of India.

Fee: $5.00 (payable via Venmo or cash to your guide Joey Israel, at start of tour)

results.description:
We'll be seeing - - -

Shakespeare's Star Turn in America

     Above: 1870 Stereogram of Edwin Booth costumed for                  the graveyard scene in his production of "Hamlet."


In celebration of the enduring inspiration of William Shakespeare’s plays, The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts will present an exhibition in its Astor Gallery. Using artifacts from the Library’s own collections, the exhibition will document the ongoing popularity of Shakespeare’s plays in North America from Colonial times to present day. The artifacts include broadsides and programs, engravings and photographs, original set and costume designs, set models and costumes, letters detailing tour conditions, and prompt scripts used by Edwin Booth, Orson Welles, Katharine Hepburn, and actors in recent Shakespeare Festival productions.

Discover which plays were performed when and where, and how they served American social history. The exhibition highlights well-known classics, such as Hamlet, Romeo and Juliet and Macbeth, and also directs attention to plays with particular historic relationships, such as King John, which was popular just before and after the Revolution, the Roman history plays, frequently performed in the 1930s for their emphasis on political responsibility, and the pageant version of The Tempest, specifically created for the 1916 Tercentenary. Artifacts and media for Much Ado about Nothing and other comedies are also displayed, revealing the non-traditional casting and period switches typical of contemporary American Shakespeare festivals.

results.description:
Many members have been asking for our Saturday Figure Drawing Session.

Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of The Flatiron District.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.) 

• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.   

• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels.  

• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

Our amazing space!

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
Come and join us for the first session of the Intro to Programming concepts seminar. This seminar is intended to help develop the meetup participants in understanding programming concepts, the foundation of all programming languages today. With a solid grasp of programming concepts and with an understanding of how they are used within the context of one programming language, people can see these concepts being applied to other languages, and can begin to understand the ideas and intentions of code in other languages.

It is important to understand that although a programing language is not being taught, that a programming language is needed to teach these concepts. The seminar will be taught around the PHP and JavaScript web programming and scripting languages and will be demonstrated using online tools to execute including PHP Fiddle (http://phpfiddle.org/), JS Fiddle (https://jsfiddle.net/), and various other appropriate fiddle programs in order to show examples in other languages.

In the course of this session, the following will be covered.

- Introduction: Explain the importance of learning concepts and how concepts are almost universal across programming languages.

- Variables: Understanding the purpose and use of variables in programming

- Simple Mathematical and Common Operations: Show basic mathematical operators and how they are used commonly in most languages.

- Dev environment: Use of a dev environment to practice concepts. PHPFiddle and JSFiddle

- Best Code Formatting practices: Best code formatting practices

- Assignment: A basic assignment for you to understand the concepts covered in the seminar.

Laptops are not required, but are recommended for this session. Wifi is available and there are power outlets and surge protectors available in the space.

There will be a $10 charge for this session that is used to cover the cost of the space. The space will hold 24 people, so we will need to cap registration at 24 at this time.

If you are interested in attending after registration has closed, you should add yourself to the waiting list on this event and email me at [masked] and I will work with space availability and/or create a future event of this session on a first-come first served basis.

For those that are registered, and cannot make it, please mark that you are not-attending this event and email me at [masked] as soon as you are aware of this! It allows others an opportunity to attend the event and myself an opportunity to recoup the expenses for renting the space.

I want to thank you for being a part of this incredible community of ladies and I look forward to meeting you.
results.name: Intro to Programming Concepts (Part 1) - Introduction, Variables and Operators

results.description:
From Goodreads--
"A wondrous and redemptive debut novel, set in a stark world where evil and magic coincide, The Enchanted combines the empathy and lyricism of Alice Sebold with the dark, imaginative power of Stephen King.

"This is an enchanted place. Others don't see it, but I do."

The enchanted place is an ancient stone prison, viewed through the eyes of a death row inmate who finds escape in his books and in re-imagining life around him, weaving a fantastical story of the people he observes and the world he inhabits. Fearful and reclusive, he senses what others cannot. Though bars confine him every minute of every day, he marries magical visions of golden horses running beneath the prison, heat flowing like molten metal from their backs, with the devastating violence of prison life.

Two outsiders venture here: a fallen priest, and the Lady, an investigator who searches for buried information from prisoners' pasts that can save those soon-to-be-executed. Digging into the background of a killer named York, she uncovers wrenching truths that challenge familiar notions of victim and criminal, innocence and guilt, honor and corruption-ultimately revealing shocking secrets of her own.

Beautiful and transcendent, The Enchanted reminds us of how our humanity connects us all, and how beauty and love exist even amidst the most nightmarish reality."

The total voting from the poll and the January Meetup--

The Enchanted by Rene Denfeld--11

Tigerman by Nick Harkaway--6

Cat's Eye by Margaret Atwood--5
results.name: March -- The Enchanted by Rene Denfeld

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". THERE IS NO NEED TO POST WHY YOU CAN'T MAKE THE EVENT. 

HAVE EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING. PLEASE DRESS PROPERLY FOR THE VERY COOL WEATHER CONDITIONS DURING THE EARLY SPRING. WHEN WE ARE WALKING AROUND MALBA, WE WILL BE NEAR THE WATERFRONT, SO IT WILL FEEL COLDER THERE!

I also scheduled this same walk on Saturday, February 27th.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will occasionally comment on some things (the architecture and social history of some of the new/old buildings in the neighborhoods of Northern Flushing, Victorian Whitestone, and Malba) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will, once in a while, stop at points of interest. This walk is about 5 miles and moderate paced. (IF YOU CAN'T KEEP UP WITH A MODERATE PACE FOR 5 MILES, THEN THIS WALK IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU.)

According to the MTA website, the No. 7 subway train will have normal service going from Manhattan to Flushing on Saturday, March 26th.

http://travel.mtanyct.info/serviceadvisory/routeStatusResult.aspx?tag=7&date=03/26/2016&time=&method=getstatus4

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John (the Event Host) who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. 

Description: We'll be walking through three neighborhoods: Northern Flushing, Whitestone, and Malba. Some of the old houses in these neighborhoods have survived; while others have been demolished for modern development.  We'll be viewing a number of old houses including the "stockbroker" English Tudor, a surprisingly cute miniature French Second Empire house, a Queen-Anne style beauty, a green-roofed house with multicolored tiling, and a mansard roofed boarding house that once housed the working-class in the 19th century. We'll also be looking at some of the newer buildings including a salmon-colored stucco palazzo, Mediterrean-style palaces with red Spanish tiled roofs, Afghan Mosque made partly of mable, Greek Orthodox Church with multiple round domes, Korean Buddhist Temple made of wood, and Russian Orthodox Church with an onion-shaped blue dome.

The neighborhood of Malba doesn't have any commercial establishments, multi-family homes, or public transportation; therefore, people living in Malba usually travel around by automobile or boat/yacht. Some call Malba the "Beverly Hills of the East Coast." We'll first look at some of the houses in Northern Flushing and then head to Whitestone, which has some lovely Victorian-era houses and new churches. However, we'll have to walk (about 15 to 20 blocks) through a mostly ordinary-looking section of Whitestone to get to an interesting section of Whitestone and ritzy Malba.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer’s Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time/Place:  The meeting time is (after lunch) at 1:45 PM. The meeting place is outside of the entrance to McDonalds Restaurant at[masked] Roosevelt Avenue (on the north side of the street between Main Street and Union Street).

THERE ARE AT LEAST TWO MCDONALDS RESTAURANT IN FLUSHING. WE ARE MEETING AT THE MACDONALDS RESTAURANT ON ROOSEVELT AVENUE , NOT MAIN STREET.

Before the walk, restrooms are available in Macy's Department Store, which is directly across the street from McDonald's Restaurant. The restrooms in Macy's are located on the second floor, next to the Shoe/Sneaker Department.

Public Transportation by subway: Take the No. 7 subway train to Main Street, Flushing. This is the last stop on the No. 7 train subway. Allow extra time because this train makes local stops to Main Street, Flushing.

Public Transportation by the LIRR: You can also take the Long Island Railroad from Nassau County to Flushing, Queens OR the Long Island Railroad from Penn Station in Manhattan to Flushing, Queens. Below is the schedule of the Port Washington Branch of the Long Island Railroad.

http://web.mta.info/lirr/Timetable/Branch/PortWashingtonBranch.pdf

Finishing Time/Place:  The walk finishes about 5:15 PM at 14th Avenue/Parsons Bouvelard (just outside of Malba). At that point, we'll be taking a bus, the Q 44 (which is a NYC bus) back to Main Street/39th Avenue in Flushing. The Q 44 bus has frequent service on Saturdays, running about every 8 or 9 minutes.

Because the Q 44 is a select bus service (SBS), passengers will have to pay the fare at a machine (which is at the bus stop) before boarding the bus and then get a receipt of payment from the machine. Paying the fare this way speeds up the boarding process. You can also buy a Metrocard at another machine located at this bus stop.

The bus ride from 14th Avenue/Parsons Boulevard to Main Street, Flushing takes about 14 minutes. You can then use the Metrocard to transfer from the city bus  to the subway (No. 7 train). This is only one fare.

Rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions or the forecast is for rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Saturday morning. This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.

(Below Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, March 13, 1927)

Below was Richard Hellman's mansion in Northern Flushing. Richard Hellman began selling mayonnaise that was made from his wife's recipe. He later trademarked his "Blue Ribbon" mayonnaise label. In 1915, Hellman built this stately mansion that was surrounded by plenty of lawn space, but a developer tore the mansion down in the 1950s and replaced it with a sprawling garden apartment complex. Even though a number of these beautiful houses on Northern Flushing have been torn down, some houses/mansions still stand.(Source Driscoll, James, Flushing[masked], NY:Arcadia Publishing, 2005)

The real estate partners who created Malba in 1908 arranged the initials of their surnames: George A. Maycock, Sammuel R. Avis, George W. Lewis, Nobel P. Bishop, and David A. Alling. They were affiliated with the Realty Trust Company, run by William Ziegler, the Baking Powder King. (Below Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, October 3, 1908)

(Below Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, April 29, 1923)

Below is Malba today. Many of the big older homes were bought and gutted to the ground only to be replaced with even bigger and more spectacular mansions. Only zoning laws prevent these houses from becoming even bigger!
results.name: Northern Flushing to Malba, Queens Walk (Mar 26)

Hi Everyone,

This month's Meetup will take place at my new studio.  We will be shooting with both natural light (I have a huge 10x14 northern facing window) and studio strobes. This Meetup is for all levels. I will help anyone that needs assistance during the shoot.

What You Need To Bring:  Good vibes and your camera gear 

Shooting Procedure:  (2PM-4PM) Each photographer, in turn, will assume the role of "Lead Photographer." The lead photographer will have the prerogative for directing the model. The other photographers may shoot at all times, but they may not direct the model or block the lead photographer, until it is their turn. A photographer may cede their turn as lead photographer.  Photographers should limit their time to a few minutes at most, since other photographers will be waiting to photograph the model.  Complicated props, & clothing, which require excessive setup or dressing times must be avoided. 

Shooting Procedure: (4PM-5PM) Photographers will have the option to pay models directly for "1 on 1 shoot time" at the price of $1 per minute.  During this time, models will be willing to do "Calvin Klien" looks like the ones below:


What will be provided: 2 models (1 male, 1 female), reflectors, strobes and remote triggers. (Model line-up is subject to change based on flakiness) Models will provide a non-commercial release. 

Investment: The price is $55.  RSVP is required and the Meetup will be limited to 10 members to maximize shooting time.  A $5 payment is required at the time that you RSVP to hold your spot. $50 will be collected the day of the Meetup. You may make payment by using the "pay now" option, PayPal, Venmo, Chase QuickPay or by cash in person. You can just pay $55 the day of the shoot, but your space is not guaranteed.  Please contact me ahead of time for any special arrangements.  I WILL NOT hold spaces for anyone, just to be fair to other members.  There are no refunds for this Meetup.

Please contact me directly with any payment questions. [masked] 

NOTE:  This Meetup is being offered to photographers that are not on this site also.  Spots will be removed as those photographers RSVP.  If you plan on attending this event, it is suggested that you RSVP as soon as you are sure.

Greetings and Salutations, Fellow Game-Geeks:

Okay, am I the only one who thinks it's weird that February--the shortest month of the year--actually *feels* like the longest?

Hm. I thought not.

In that case, let us (hopefully) shed our winter coats and greet the arrival of spring with a friendly afternoon of gaming at our favorite spot, Zeppelin Hall Biergarten & Restaurant.

For those of you not in the know, Zeppelin Hall is located near the Jersey Avenue light rail station, and just a few blocks south of the Grove Street PATH. There is also ample parking in the parking lot at the end of Jersey Avenue. With its convenient location, its wide variety of on-tap craft beers, and its extensive menu of Bavarian treats as well as traditional pub favorites, ZH has quickly emerged as the group's favorite gaming spot. Join us for an afternoon, and we think you'll see why.

Hope to see everyone there!

YFL
results.name: Board Games, Beer, & Bratwurst: March Into Spring

results.description:
Out in Corona Queens exists this brightly colored gem tucked around a corner that you could easily miss but shouldn't. Tortilleria Nixtamal is one of those spots that is a hidden oasis in the middle of nowhere that not too many people know about.


For the uninitiated Nixtamal is the maker of masa and masa based products for some of the top restaurants and markets in the city. From that masa they make chips, tortillas and other products used in Mexican cooking. Being part factory/part restaurant we get the spoils of getting some of the freshest products available all made in-house.  Outside of their amazing masa based products, the food is simply divine.

One of my favorite things they do is the parrillada molcajete with the "build your own taco" combination option. It looks and tastes amazing and is a tacoholics wet dream.


Join us for this spring time excursion to Queens for some of the best Mexican food you will ever have. They also sell their products to the public so if you want to purchase some of their amazing chips, masa or salsas that is totally doable.


After having dinner here I plan to take you all to an amazing Italian bakery for some desserts as well as some local street fare in the heart of queens. This will be a great day indeed. Be There!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet us inside of Nixtamal for what will be a grand feast of goodness...
results.name: Masa Meet Frank - Frank Meet Masa (Legit Mexican in Queens)

results.description:
Poetry takes dynamic energy and form, like water and its shape. Deepen your experience of this fluid and infinite art by diving into this immersive workshop, designed to strengthen and nourish your poetry practice. 

This six-week course will be taught by A. Anupama, a local poet, translator, teacher, and founding editor of River River. All participants will write new poems, read and discuss current literary publications, give and receive peer feedback, and reflect on poetic craft essays to gain new writing and revision techniques. Heighten your poetic inspiration this spring, right through National Poetry Month!

Scholarships available through application here: http://goo.gl/forms/DfvxfdrlUl
