results.description:
Join me for one of the Garden State's Finest Hikes!  The Bearfort Ridge sits on the edge of the Wawayanda Plateau, offering unique landscapes and excellent views of Greenwood Lake, Sterling Forest, the Jersey Highlands, and New York City on the horizon.  The ridge itself features interesting rock formations and a variety of wildlife

Length: ~4 Miles

Elevation Gain: ~1000 Feet

Map: NYNJTC North Jersey Trails (please bring your own!)

Conditions: This is a relatively easy hike for beginner and intermediate hikers, but it is not a walk.  There are rocks, a couple of very short scrambles, and a few steep sections.

BE PREPARED.  Only you know how much food and water you need for a 7.5 mile hike Bring enough to get through the day.  Pack appropriate gear for a day in the woods.  Please see REI's 10 Essentials list for minimum gear suggestions: http://www.rei.com/learn/expert-advice/ten-essentials.html

For More Information:

http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/abram-s-hewitt-state-forest

http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/abram-s-hewitt-state-forest-0

http://www.nynjtc.org/files/NYNJTC_AbramSHewitt2015_WebsiteMap.pdf


THE FINE PRINT -- PLEASE NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. The full waiver can be found on the HVH LEGAL DISCLAIMER page.
results.name: Last Minute Bearfort Ridge

results.description:
Join us for a period of meditation and Dhamma discussion on Western Buddhism with Bhante Suddhāso & Bhante Saddhasara.

Bhante Saddhasara joined the Mahamevnawa Meditation Monastery in Sri Lanka in 2005, became a novice in 2006 under Ven. Kiribatgoda Gnanananda Thero, and after two years of study and practice, attained High Ordination in 2009. After three more years of study, he had begun to develop a deep understanding of insight and tranquility techniques. In 2012 he was asked to begin and to organize a meditation center in Tampa, Florida to provide training to all those who wished to learn. The center was to be non-denominational; anyone of any religion could come and study the practices. Bhante Saddhasara also offered a Recovery Program for those suffering from addiction; an introductory mindfulness program for children; a prison program; and, throughout Florida and throughout the U.S.A, he also gave lectures and provided mindfulness and meditation teaching, as well as private counseling to adults and to youths of all ages. Bhante Saddhasara speaks fluent English and very much enjoys the back and forth of his conversations with Americans.
results.name: LOWER EAST SIDE: 6pm Meditation with Bhante Suddhāso & Bhante Saddhasara

results.description:
Come and receive - spiritual nourishment and an opportunity to relax and rejuvenate - in the physical and every other sense. We've had some amazing gatherings Sunday after Sunday - sunshine for the soul through each and every one's Light - their presence and spiritual participation. This is what make Neolyth such a well of positive atmosphere - community gatherings of kindred spirits. We are 'spiritual beings having a human experience' and every one has unique gifts to offer from and through their Soul.

These gatherings will now provide a space to lie down in Savasana or relaxation pose while listening to live sound of alchemical crystal bowls, guided imagery, and spiritually oriented ancient verse and poetry. The door will remain open for you to come in quietly and find a comfortable mat and seat. Small donations appreciated!

results.description:
Q&A WITH DIRECTOR JULIO HERNÁNDEZ CORDÓN

MeetUp Members save $4 on tickets -
Enter promo codeNDNF2016 (case-sensitive) in the upper right corner.
http://purchase.filmlinc.org/single/SelectSeating.aspx?p=30753

Miguel (Diego Calva) and Johnny (Eduardo Eliseo Martinez) are in deep. Badass skater-bros, crazy-in-love blood hustlers, they’re flowing inevitably toward a sea swimming with narco-sharks. This is Mexico City today, and for two boys from different worlds but the same house—Johnny is the son of Miguel’s family maid—there is no future. On the days they do have at their disposal, they will live as hard as they can, even if it means total destruction for everyone around them. A harrowing vision of the 21st century replete with garishly lit sex scenes, inebriated slow motion, and an exhilarating, eclectic pop soundtrack, and winner of numerous prizes at festivals in Latin America, Julio Hernández Cordón’s film is exploding with beats, sweat, and pain—an ecstatic and anguished portrait of youth teetering on the brink of nihilism.
results.name: Te Prometo Anarquía (I Promise You Anarchy) @ Film Society of Lincoln Center

results.description:
New Swing Dance Session With Spencer @ The JCC in Manhattan

334 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY @76th street

 with  Spencer Weisbond

Six week, progressive session : Mar 13, 2016-Apr 17, 2016
Sun
7:30PM - 8:30PM & 8:30PM - 9:30PM
# of Sessions: 6
Except:  Feb 7th No class!
  102: Advanced Beginner -  7:30 -8:30pm Advance in Jitterbug and East Coast Swing by learning more involved patterns with harder footwork. Build your dance vocabulary and partnering skills. This class is the prerequisite for Lindy Hop (level 3), which is the grandfather of all swing dances and has 8-count patterns. No partner needed


  103: Lindy Hop﻿ Pre-Intermediate 8:30- 9:30pm
Bring all your moves together into complete sequences. Learn new eight-count patterns to make your dance more intricate and expressive.  

  Teacher: Spencer Weisbond please call me with questions about your level[masked]
Level one is now on Wednesday nights!
  Register and pricing below:

  Level 102: http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=643452733&_ga=1.167298430.1141896589.1397581416

Level 103: http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=643452749&_ga=1.201402577.1141896589.1397581416 </a>

Spencer has been dancing swing since 1998. He has studied Lindy hop extensively with 4 time world champion and 8 time American champion, Nathalie Gomes. Spencer had led the outreach program for Hop Swing And & Jump dance studios at local venues around NYC.
Spencer has had his own program in swing at the JCC in Manhattan for over 8 years, and also teaches privately. He has taught for Lincoln Center’s “Midsummer Night Swing” He currently organizes the New York City Swing Dance Meetup Group, which has over 3400 members, making it one of the most active swing dance clubs in the world. Spencer also co-founded the popular NYC dance  event “Swing Remix”. <a href="http://www.SwingRemix.com">www.SwingRemix.com </a> <a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=135393">

<a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=135408"></a>

results.description:
I want to thank everyone who came out for this, What a great show and an amazing meetup. I met some of the most fun and amazing people, the comics were a full top Comedy Central line up too. For those of you who havent been to this, This is a special Meetup, we finally got a deal with Stand Up New York the hottest club in New York City to let us in free of charge and see comics like Amy Shumer, Godfrey, Kevin Brennan and top names, this is NOT an amateur show like alot of the meetups. I just ask that everyone who Rsvp's really do their best to show up AND MAKE IT ON TIME. as you know I dont charge for this meetup so come out see the hottest comedy show and maybe even make some new friends. this sundays line up includes the below.

Host: Goumba Johnny (Hot 103.5, Sirius, Howard Stern Show) Brings you , Gregory K. (Orange is the New Black), Gary Vider (Comedy Central), Al D. (Comedy Central), Sam Morril (Comedy Central, Last Comic Standing), Yamaneika Saunders (Meredith Veira show, Last Comic Standing, Funny Girls Reality Series), Kareem Green (Comedy Central) and pretty much any comic you see on Comedy Central these days drops by and shows up on the lineup who knows who might drop by usually its Amy Shumer or Judah Friedlander.

there will be an organizer by the iphone charger as usual to meet with everyone and give you tickets for free admission and have everyone sit together so we can all share laughs. Try to be early the show starts at 8 and everyone sits at same table but i do this earlier so all of you can meet your fellow meetup members.

This is a 2 show ticket, so if you show up for the 8 you can stay for the ten also which has a different but also comedy central lineup. Or if you would like to come for the 10 you can just say meetup at the door and they will point you to me.
results.name: Comedy Central Meetup at Stand Up New York Free admission 2 drnk min Greg K

results.description:
We've planned this now as a weekly meetup, so that everyone in the group can get together even if the moderator can't be there.

If Darren can't make it to introduce everyone (he can't this week), could someone please take it upon themselves to 1) stake out the big table a little early, 2) Lead a go-around-the-horn o? introductions at 8pm, and 3) Time the 60 minutes of writing time and let everyone know when it's 9 pm.

As always,

Please RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change. We have had far too many no-shows.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.

Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

7-8 pm - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
8:00 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on
8:05 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
9:05- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like. Feel free to keep writing if you've got the momentum going! Be aware Argo closes at 10pm.
If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. It may just be "pipe-cleaning" for now, but you'll feel better showing up at the page. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: Argo Tea Cafe, Columbus Circle Subway Station. 1792 Broadway.

SOME TIPS:

Argo has plenty of outlets - we will be on the back, large table.
Seats are hard to come by, and I can only save so many, so please, come on time! If you come late, we might have already started.
The music and occasionally nonmember conversation can be loud, so bring headphones too.
WiFi is available with purchase.
It's a little chilly, so if you get cold bring a sweater.
And it goes without saying that buying a cup of joe or a snack from Argo for being nice enough to host us will bring you good writing karma.
If you aren't sure you can make it, please don't RSVP! Come on time or even a little early, as it can be difficult to save seats.
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Columbus Circle

results.description:
10,000 PB&Js is a volunteer led organization that meets each week in White Plains & the lower east side to make and assemble several hundred meals and then distribute them in small teams throughout Manhattan to the homeless.

The PB&Js and Hershey Kisses are their starting point: a means to begin a conversation, to listen and lay the foundation of trust necessary to offer more substantial help.

THIS EVENT IS FOR MEAL DISTRIBUTION: 

Volunteers gather on East 11th street for orientation, then break up into teams of 3 or 4 volunteers distributing food, clothing & toiletries on pre-assigned routes. Finish times vary by team: some will be done before 11 pm and other teams might work until midnight. 

THIS IS A RECURRING EVENT: 

10,000 PB&Js typically feeds a couple hundred neighbors each Sunday night and would be thrilled to extend up to 8 distribution spots to NYC Volunteer Opportunities members each week. 

TO JOIN: RSVP here or feel free to check out 10,000 PB&Js group: www.meetup.com/10000PBandJs

CAN'T ATTEND BUT WANT TO HELP?

Here's the link to 10,000's Wish List: https://goo.gl/qwXAY7
results.name: Volunteer with 10,000 PB&Js

Hey Challengers,

Hope you are all well and enjoying the Fall.

I am offering an Energy Transmission on Sunday Nights at 10PM, especially for weight loss!

Good nutrition is the core, for good health and successful weight loss, and good energy nutrition is important as well.

This will help you to relax, recharge, replenish, and will help you with stress eating, cravings, and to keep focused, and to feel better about your body and yourself.

A special and delicious vitamin essence, will fill you up with good nutrition, which will help you fill up with the good stuff, therefore you will feel more satisfied with less food, and helps you to absorb the nutrients your body needs.

This will also relax and strengthen your adrenal glands, and help to revitalize all of your glands and organs.

I really hope you enjoy this gift, and if you have any questions  concerns, please let me know.

I will have this each and every Sunday at 10PM! And, in the comfort of your own home.

All you need to do is relax, and intend to receive the Weight Loss Energy Transmission from Jae.

It's that easy, and then you can just relax and enjoy! Do not worry about falling asleep, because the energies work great while you're sleeping. They will work even if you are distracted or if you forget.

All you need to do is to RSVP so that you are on the list.

Please RSVP for each week that want to be included so that I know you're in.

Hope you'll participate in the next Weight Loss Challenge in October!

I'd love to see you!

Hope to see you real soon!

 

All the very best,

Jae

facebook.com/groups/therisenyc

----------------------------------------------

This one workout will keep you amped up all week long. Seriously, give it a try and you will be hooked!


The exercises may change from week to week, but it is always a Tabata-style interval workout: 20 seconds of high intensity work followed by 10 seconds of rest. Then repeat! Exercises include sprints, burpees, squats, situps, box jumps, step ups, pushups, dips, and other “no-frills” exercises.


Warm up beforehand by running, biking, or walking. We start promptly at 6:30 AM and the workout only lasts 31 minutes. Show up a few minutes early to meet people and get yourself pumped up.

results.description:
Every week we will have a different prompt for our weekly photo project.  This week’s theme is Jewelry 

Each week beginning early Monday morning, you can begin uploading your photos to our meetup album for the week’s theme.  The group won’t actually meet for this event, it’s an individual online challenge for each of you to get your creative juices flowing, share photos in the group, comment and critique each other’s shots, and above all have fun. 

Albums will remain open, so you can upload photos any time after that Monday morning start time but you’ll get the most feedback during the initial week the theme is posted.  You also don’t have to restrict yourself to photos taken during that week for the theme, they can be from past shoots you have done or the weekly prompt can be used to motivate you to shoot something new.

Please consider sharing your project photos with our other chapters on our Facebook group.
results.name: Weekly Photo Project - Jewelry

results.description:
The purpose of a restorative yoga is healing. We utilize yoga postures (asana's) and breathing techniques (pranayama), to inhibit the stress response To activate the healing and repairing systems for optimal health.

For someone to heal, they must first reduce stress. Straining to keep the body in a pose is counterproductive to the healing process, because it elicits the stress response.  

Stress weakens the immune system, therefore the body's ability to repair itself or to ward off disease is stunted. In a restorative class we execute poses that open, and restore the body, still the mind, and balance the breath.

We use blankets that are folded and rolled to support and prop the body to assist the postures. The postures are held, and rested in during the class time.  Each students is asked to bring as many towels, or blankets they would like to enhance their experience in this class. The use of props to completely support the body as it rests for a period of time in a healing position is known as Restorative Yoga.

Class fee is $12

class is for one hour

blankets are available for purchase fee is $20
results.name: Restorative Yoga Class

results.description:
For coworking space, it's first come first served. You'll want to get there early to find a desk before it fills up. The space is available from 10am to 6pm. If you are planning on attending, you'll need to do the following things:

• Register at the AWS Pop-up Loft Space - https://aws.amazon.com/start-ups/loft/ny-loft/

• Once you are registered you can pick up a badge and attend any of the co-working meetups.

• Let us know you are going by signing up for the event on meetup. This also lets other people in the group know who is going to be there too.

• Remember to check the Pop-up Loft website to make sure it is open. We'll do out best to cancel meetups on holidays and days the space won't be available but you should also double check before coming out.

• While there are snacks and drinks at the space, lunch is not provided. There are a number of restaurants, delis and other places to get food in the area so plan accordingly

• These daily coworking events are self run. A co-organizer will not always be at the event. These events are designed to give game developers a free space to work so you'll basically be left alone at the space to do you own thing. We suggest reaching out to other attending through the comments to sit together or meet up at a specific time in the space.

Last thing, two times a month we'll have a dedicated space for you to come out and work as well as listen to talks and get help from myself and others in the community. Those will be different events you'll need to register for which are separate from the daily co-working space.

results.description:
Classes are created for those with physical disabilities, aliments, recovering from surgery, Seniors OR who are seeking a gentle practice to restore the body and mind.
Classes will include poses and methods that will allow students to increase muscular strength, endurance, flexibility as well as stamina, lung capacity and overall wellness. While experiencing the positive effects Yoga has on the mind-body connection. We will practice our asana's (postures) with the use of a chair. Students can either remain seated through the session or stand and use the back of the chair while standing. Asana's are expressed both ways,so the student can find the expression that works best for their needs.

Postures are modified into variations designed to fit each individuals needs.
Classes will be held in an atmosphere that is extraordinary, surrounded by beautiful stain glass windows inside the actual church. That will complement the tranquility and peace of our practice.These classes have no bearing on religious beliefs and are open to all.
Please join me at The All Saints Episcopal Church 2329 Victory Blvd. Staten Island, N.Y. 10314.

Mondays and Fridays 11:00 am. 

Class fee is $12, or $10 for seniors.

results.description:
Join other new mamas at these meetings tailored to moms of newborns up to 12 months old. We'll discuss the ups and downs of life with a newborn/baby -- all aspects of breastfeeding (successes and challenges), the realities of caring for a baby, navigating the new world of parenting, sleeping patterns (or lack thereof) for you and your baby, and much more. But most importantly, the hope is that you will meet other Rivertown/Westchester moms of babies who will become treasured new friends. This is a group for all new mamas, including second-timers and formula-feeding mamas. The group size varies from week to week, but it's typically 6-10 moms. Further information is available here:

http://www.rivertownmamas.com/groups.html

The group operates on a pay-what-you-wish model, and payment is made anonymously (unless paid by credit card). Suggested: $20 per meeting.
results.name: New moms' discussion group

Join this special free LIVE online event from across the world.

With meditation and visualisation, this powerful 30 minute broadcast features beautiful sounds and music to uplift, energise and inspire.

Experience the benefit of the enhanced collective energy of meditating with other people, whilst being in the comfort of your own home or office.

Each meditation includes an introduction, followed by a time in which to meditate in whatever way is easy and natural to you.

You are then guided through a visualisation enabling you to focus on living your ideal life.

Participating Live:

The broadcast begins promptly at 2.00pm and finishes at 2.30pm.

***Please click to join Meditation 101 Live at the scheduled broadcast time ***

Please note that the meditation and visualisation are pre-recorded to ensure sound quality however participation with other people from across the world is live.

Meditation 101 Live works best with the following internet browsers: Internet Explorer, Chrome, Safari and Opera.

If you need any technical help connecting to Meditation 101 Live please click here.

My two-and-a-half, Oscar, and I so enjoy reading books in French together that we thought what could be better than to read with friends? Bisous,

results.description:
Our twice-monthly meeting of business professionals takes place from 4pm - 5pm in a private meeting room at the restaurant.

While there are many ways to make connections with potential new clients, nothing is better than having that prospect's trusted advisor pick up a phone or send an e-mail that says, "Here's someone you need to speak with about that problem you're having".  This is exactly what the members of Smart Transition Group do for each other.  We get to know each other, we get to trust each other, and then we share our most valuable resource... our clients.  

We all want to grow our businesses, but doing it personally, face-to-face, with people you trust and appreciate, makes it faster, easier, and far more effective.  Come learn more as a guest of the group at one of our upcoming meetings.  Bring your best-self, and a stack of business cards.

We'll take an opportunity to introduce ourselves and get to know other members. We will often have a featured member who will expand on the details of their business and help us to understand their buying signs so that we know who to think of when we hear them from our clients.

After a good discussion and a recap of the progress we will retire to the bar at Morton's for a drink and a more relaxed discussion. Some say, that's where the business really happens.

This is a great way to spend some time on a Monday afternoon growing your network and building alliances.
results.name: Monday Meetings at Morton's (The Steakhouse)

group.name: Smart Transition Group - Business Networking that Works

results.description:
“Fabulous Fabrics from Five Continents” collected by Judy Manton, adjunct professor of cross-cultural studies at Fairleigh Dickinson University, will be exhibited at the Southeast Senior Center for Independent Living (SESCIL) March 28th thru April 10th. The exhibit is being co-sponsored by the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of the Palisades.

Most of the fabrics are hand-woven or hand decorated. Techniques include tie dye, batik, applique, hand-printing and embroidery on silk, cotton, bark cloth and goat hair. Some of the extraordinary pieces are a Coptic cotton fragment, intensely embroidered wedding kurtas from the Sindh in Pakistan, exquisite embroidered pieces from minority areas in China and Judy’s heirloom which is a handwoven, wool bedspread dating back to 1848. Other special pieces are a silk applique of the eight precious treasures of Buddhism made for Manton in a monastery in Tibet and pictorial story cloth made in a refugee camp by a woman from Laos who embroidered her escape from the Pathet Lao.

The opening night event on March 28th from 5:00 – 7:00 p.m. will feature not only a power point presentation by Manton showing fabric artists at work around the world, but also a trousseau of Turkish fabrics inherited by Irene Danis-Kremen, former textile designer and stylist. Refreshments will be served. For reservations, call (SESCIL) at[masked]-4080.

EXHIBIT HOURS THROUGH APRIL 10th:

Tuesdays & Thursdays – 2:30-4:00

Fridays – 3:00-4:00

Saturdays – 1:00-4:00

Sundays – 1:00-4:00
results.name: Fabulous Fabrics From Five Continents Exhibit

results.description:
Apply Here: http://beginnerprogrammers.nyc/full-stack-bootcamp/


Overview:


Become a full stack developer who understands the power of the HTML while being able to control and create robust Ruby on Rails applications. Take This Course, and you will enjoy a 12 week bootcamp where you will leave with several web apps and critical thinking skills.

Our Structure:


Students will attend class 4 times weekly while being given homework assignments and projects to work on outside of class. You will also have direct communication with each of your instructors and TA’s before, during, and after the bootcamp completes.


Our weekend Peer Programming events are also a great way to sharpen your programming skills and complete assignments amongst fellow coders.


Class Setup:


The best educations come from small class sizes and direct instruction, period. You will be part of a class no larger than 10 students.


Preparing You for the Real World:


Select students will be given immediate internship opportunities as an Rails developer with some of the startups that we work with. During the final month of the boot camp, each student will spend time shadowing a developer at a tech startup to gain experience and interact with an actual developer.


We will also refer you to available positions through our extensive network after teaching you vital interviewing skills needed to be a self sufficient developer.


Pre-requisites:

No previous programming experience is required, but we would recommend you at least take one of our free appetizer courses on www.beginnerprogrammers.nyc

Please bring a laptop capable of running either Linux or Mac-OSX

Install Ruby and Rails 4. (Send an email if you need help with this step.)

Install Sublime Text:  http://www.sublimetext.com/


Instructor: Alain Goldman

Ruby on Rails Developer @ www.lootfly.com

CTO of Beginner Programmers: www.beginnerprogrammers.nyc

Organizer of: http://www.meetup.com/BeginnerProgrammers/

Email: [masked]

Cost: $2500  financing/payment plans available)

Start/End Date: March 28th - June 20th

Schedule: Mon - Thurs | 5:30pm - 7pm

Apply Here: http://beginnerprogrammers.nyc/full-stack-bootcamp/ 


For questions regarding this bootcamp, please contact Alain Goldman at [masked]
results.name: Full Stack Web Dev BootCamp (Part Time : 12 Weeks)

results.description:
45 minutes of diving into the teachings, techniques, and practice of Meditation, for new and experienced Meditators.

All meditations are meant to purify our heart and bring our mind to its natural condition. Our consciousness is inherently pure, eternal, full of knowledge and bliss. But somehow or other it has been covered by and adulterated by so many misconceptions, so many desires, so many longings, so many anxieties about what we want and what we don’t want. 

When you look into a mirror, you see yourself. But what if that mirror has been neglected for hundreds of years? There are layers and layers of debris, dust, dirt and filth. And when you look into that mirror, all you see is the dust and the dirt that is accumulated, and all that you think is “This is me!” But when you clean the mirror, little by little you start seeing the image of yourself. And when the mirror is actually clean, you see who you are. Meditation is for that purpose; prayers are for that purpose; spirituality is for that purpose: to cleanse our heart, to cleanse our life-style so that we can actually directly experience our own essence, which is eternal, full of knowledge and full of love
results.name: Let's meet up and Meditate

results.description:
Come for the sheer joy of moving to the music, in a nurturing and supportive setting.

Whether you have never danced before or want to continue, this is a class for you.

The classes are one hour and half in length and provide quality instruction.

Ballet is one of the most healthy and intense forms of dance.
It can provide a complete full-body workout, increasing your flexibility, range of motion and strength.

It’s also a great alternative to aerobics.

The classes are on-going, join in anytime.

PRICES Walk-Ins: $20.
Package: $180 for a card of 10 classes (over a course of 6 months).
Talk to us about multiple class per week discount!

ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR
Bruce Weitzmon is a choreographer, dancer and teacher. His work has been presented in the U.S.A. and Canada. Bruce was the director of the Theater Dance Center, a non-profit dance education and performance organization in Rockland County, founded in 1981. After many years directing TDC, he returned to New York City to teach. Now after more than 10 years there, he is returning to offer a weekly schedule of classes in Nyack, NY.

VISIT US ON FACEBOOK
For more about the Dancers’ Art class schedule, rates or any additional information please visit and like Dancers’ Art on Facebook at www.facebook.com/DancersArt or call[masked]-1973.

results.description:
Please note that our group and our happy hours are not for non-Asians. 


Icebreaker Game: "NYAPM Neighborhoods"

We are continuing the eighth round of our icebreaker game.  If you are new to New York, NYAPM, or are just looking for new Asian professional friends – you might be wondering, "Who lives or works close to me so that we might hang out together?"

As before, the game will start at 6:30 pm and will run until 7:30 pm. The first 25 matches will get a free drink ticket each! Here are the rules: 

1. You must write your first and last name on the name tags, as well as the neighborhood in which you work or live (e.g., Elmhurst, Williamsburg, UWS, Midtown East, etc.).

2. Find another NYAPM member who's written down the same neighborhood as you.

3. Discuss one thing that you like most about that neighborhood and make arrangements to hang out in that neighborhood between this NYAPM happy hour and the next one.  Once you have made plans with a specific date, time, and place, you are eligible for a free drink ticket.

After completing 1, 2, and 3 above, find one of the organizers (Richard Young) or (Tiffany Ma) to get your free drinks (available only for the first 25 matches – so come on time!).

--

Our monthly happy hour is our flagship event that started it all years ago in 2005. Experience what it's all about -- come and meet fellow Asian professionals in a friendly, casual atmosphere. Relax after work and meet some new people.

Because this is a free event where you are not paying a cover or door fee, we humbly request that you please buy one drink or more to support our venue since they are turning away other business to allow us to host our event (buying alcoholic drinks/soft drinks/bottled water helps support the venue -- getting free tap/iced water does not).

First time to one of our events?  See photos from previous happy hours on Meetup or Facebook.

Hope to see you there!

Also find us on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/events/769682266510100/
results.name: March 2016 NYAPM Happy Hour

results.description:
Co-Founder of FinTech start-up Herio Capital, Patrick Janson, started his career working in finance as an underwriter for a credit fund.

After working in finance for 6 years, Patrick made the jump to tech by learning to program at a coding boot camp. He has since produced iOS apps, built a real estate crowdfunding platform and most recently, crossed $20 million in sales at his current company, Herio Capital where he heads up product management. 

An active member of the New York tech scene, Patrick will be sharing his personal story and providing  guidance about making the challenging but exciting transition from Wall Street to Silicon Ally. He will also provide insight into the FinTech scene and present more about his company.

About Byte Academy: Byte Academy offers intensive workshops, full and part-time courses including Python fullstack programming, FinTech (financial technology), Data Sciences and MedTech.  Career services, community, events and access to top industry professionals are emphasized in its programs.  Byte Academy offers scholarships for all women and comprehensive financial aid.  The school accepts applications on a rolling basis; fulltime cohorts start every 4 weeks.

Announcing the launch of our Byte Tonight Program!  Based on our favorite last minute hotel deal app - Hotel Tonight - enroll in one of the remaining spots of our April 11 full-time Python or FinTech cohort and receive 20%.  Email [masked] for details, interview scheduling and to cram in the pre-bootcamp work ASAP.  Follow in Patrick's footsteps!
results.name: Startup Talk: Herio Capital, From Coding Bootcamp to FinTech Co-Founder

results.description:
Bar Seki, the latest from the geniuses behind Sushi Seki, has started a Monday night Seki Sake Club. They've invited Stephen Lyman to introduce shochu to their sake club, which is open to the public. Come out to try shochu, and perhaps sake sommelier Yasu Suzuki will pour some special sake that he thinks is an interesting contrast to the shochu.

Have you tried shochu? The traditional distilled spirit from Japan? It's more dry than sake and much easier to drink than other spirits. Goes great when paired with food.

Stephen Lyman, editor of http://kampai.us and shochu sommelier for SakaMai and other NYC Japanese restaurants, pours selected shochu each Tuesday around NYC. The location will be on the move so stay on top of each week here on meetup or by following Stephen on twitter @kampaius
results.how_to_find_us: We will occupy the front bar and perhaps some of the tables next to it.
results.name: Shochu'sday @ Seki Sake Club

ABSOLUTELY NO CLEATS ALLOWED! NO EXCEPTIONS!! Turf shoes and indoor shoes are ay-okay.  

Permit Disclosure: We have a permit.

PLEASE BRING A WHITE SHIRT, A DARK SHIRT & A BRIGHT COLORED SHIRT

Game Host - DT

Co-leader - JJ

Location -We're playing outdoor at John Murray Playground in Long Island City.

PLEASE ARRIVE ON TIME - 5:45pM!! Teams will be picked from this time.

This session will begin at 10am sharp and and late comers will wait on the sidelines to be placed in the game. We will play two 40 minute games with 10 minutes for half time.

The game format is two 7v7 games, running simultaneously. Winners and losers of the first game will play against each other in the second game.

This game is to raise funds for Lionsraw, for more information please speak to Ben or click on this link... www.lionsraw.org

Rules:

Fun Play 
No Sliding 
Goals after half point only. 
Kick-ins.. no throw ins. 
Corner kicks. 
Kick-off at midpoint after each goal.

To promote generosity, honor and respect PS2G plays clean soccer! This means no cursing, insulting, complaining, arguing or fighting! We welcome you if this is your usual style or if you want to change your attitude to fit our culture.

The proceeds go to our charity network: http://ps2g.org/charities

***BRING TURF SHOES OR SNEAKERS & A DARK, WHITE & A BRIGHT COLORED SHIRT*** 

AGAIN - NO CLEATS ALLOWED!

All RSVPs are final. No credits or refunds. (It's all for charity anyway)

If you can't afford the meetup fees, please visit our website to learn how to become a game leader. Game Leaders play for free.

http://ps2g.org/gameleaders

PS2G enables soccer players to organize fundraising pickup games that support our charity network ultimately promoting the safe play of soccer for disadvantaged children.

Disclaimer By taking part in group activities you hereby are agreeing to the rules and regulation of the meetup. In addition, you acknowledge you are volunteering to play at your own self will and at your own risk. Neither organizer nor assistant organizers are responsible for any injuries or mishaps while partaking in the games. We encourage love of the game and for each other. We encourage friendly competition. Organizers reserve the right to remove players from the game if they refuse to be friendly.

[masked]

results.description:
We will power up the Major Welch, take in the sunset & socialize briefly at Perkins Tower, then descend on the AT.

We will meet in the main parking lot. If you are running late, you are welcome to catch up with the group if we have begun.

This is not a beginner hike. You should have some hiking experience and be getting regular exercise. While it is only four miles, there is significant elevation gain on the Major Welch.

Make sure you have a copy of the map, a headlamp, and minimum 2 liter of water. If you fall behind during the hike, you must be prepared to finish on your own. Faster hikers are not obligated to wait for slower hikers. Typically we meet at the parking lot and begin together. As we ascend, the group breaks off. We will do our best to reconvene at the peak and begin our descent together. The amount of time we spend at Perkins will depend upon the weather. You must feel comfortable hiking out on your own should you fall behind. We would love to have everyone join but due the nature of an evening event we can not make accommodations for those who are unable to hike independently. There is no sweep. If you are unsure whether or not this is for you, please email me with any questions.

Heavy rain cancels and would be determined that day if necessary.

Distance: about 4 miles

Gain: about 1200

Hike time: 2 - 3 hours

HUDSON VALLEY HIKER LEGAL DISCLAIMER & WAIVER OF LIABILITY

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

The Hudson Valley Hikers Club does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant

Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader - This is YOUR hike

Chers ami(e)s,

Thank you for making our now WEEKLY event "Jadore le French" a great success : c’était ma première surprise partie :-) Pictures posted below ! Let's meet again at Cellar Bar to speak French (or at least try a bit with Manhattans).

Special Thanks&HugsⓇ to the new members : you guys rock !Congratulations to Gabor and Abderaman, winners of the last raffle.

MegaHugsⓇ to Amelia, Hostess Etincelante, inventor of a new game using French quotes. 

French is not such a difficult language. If Rocky Balboa can speak Russian, if Rambo can speak Dari, then everybody can speak French, just a question of time :-) The new format "Jadore-le-French" is even nicer than our "Pardon-my-French" of last year.

To facilitate connections and meet&greets, we will have a special fun "lottery" :

Each of you will be given one of my polaroids (http://myinstantfilms.com/). Only TWO PAIRS will be identical. The 4 winners will get an invitation for two at Crepes & Delices, a brand new French crêperie located on 72nd and Columbus. THEY DO HAVE REAL GALETTES DE SARRASIN, AVIS AUX AMATEURS :

http://crepesanddelices.com


Come and get rewards by :

1. Dressing super nicely

2. Showing progress in your French skills (whatever you start from)

None of these are an obligation, neither a demand, just an incentive for rewards (perfumes, hats, free bottles of wine etc.).

Who are the organizers ? Yara, Handsome President, and Jean-Philippe, Glorieux Président. Since 3 weeks, Amelia, aka Superamelia, has joined the team as Hostess Étincelante.

IN THREE YEARS, WE HAVE ORGANIZED HUNDREDS OF SOCIAL EVENTS, FRENCH LESSONS/WORKSHOPS, FRENCH CONCERTS (including launching Flo, now superstar!) etc.

Pics from last Jadore le French :

Merci beaucoup et à lundi prochain !

-- Jean-Philippe, Yara, Amelia

results.description:
***Come any time between 6:00pm and 9:00pm, stay as long as you want, or leave when you need to. (Arriving at 7:00pm or 8:00pm is perfectly great.)***


Join us at The Organic Grill, where, according to New York Magazine, eating healthy is "[n]ot a problem at this East Village café where locally grown produce and artisan ingredients make up dishes like black-bean-and-roasted-peppers quesadilla with vegan cheese. Even the coffee is organic and shade-grown."

According to Timeout New York, "[t]his casual, cozy, friendly vegetarian café (with a couple of fish options on its menu) rounds up the usual suspects of herbivore cuisine: vegetables steamed or sautéed; salads; grilled-tofu sandwiches and simple macro plates."

Urban Naturale says, "[w]hen I’ve waited too long to eat, feel like I’m close to starvation and there is nothing fresh, healthy, organic or edible in my kitchen, my go-to choice for fast, organic food is Organic Grill on First Avenue in the East Village. I know that I can count on them for organic, mostly vegan, American fusion dishes that are prepared in a healthy, yet tasty way."

The Organic Grill also serves beer and wine in addition to fresh squeezed juices, smoothies, homemade sodas, and a wide assortment of teas and coffees. 


For those of you who have never attended one of our Meetup events: this is an incredibly friendly & welcoming group. It will be easy to find our group: most of the people in this small cafe will be us. (If you are unsure, just ask a waitperson.) Everyone pays for themselves. Easy!

Train Directions: The Organic Grill is conveniently accessible by subway. Take the 6 train to Astor Place, the L train to 1st Avenue, or the F train to 2nd Avenue.

Web site: http://www.theorganicgrill.com

See you at The Organic Grill!


David


***Come any time between 6:00pm and 9:00pm, stay as long as you want, or leave when you need to. (Arriving at 7:00pm or 8:00pm is perfectly great.)***

results.description:
Join us on March 28th from 6pm to 9:30pm at Lincoln Center for an evening that explores the intersection of story and play. Nick Fortugno (co-founder Playmatics and world-renowned game designer) and Lance Weiler (storyteller and director of the Columbia University Digital Storytelling Lab) will hold a fireside chat on the art and craft of narrative play - an exploration into collaborative forms of story and the play spaces that nurture them. 

Then stick around for a special Sherlock Holmes & the Internet of Things session. Step into a global storytelling experiment with over 1,200 collaborators from 60+ countries. This is a hands-on session with new technology and also an opportunity to co-create a special experience that will premiere in the Convergence section of the New York Film Festival later this fall. Together we'll re-imagine the work of Arthur Conan Doyle as we transform Lincoln Center into a massive connected crime scene for a live audience.  

The event is FREE. 

Sherlock Holmes & the Internet of Things is a prototype from the Digital Storytelling Lab at Columbia University School of the Arts. We're pleased to be partnering with the Film Society of Lincoln Center on this exciting year-long program. For more info please visit http://sherlockholmes.io
results.how_to_find_us: 144 w 65th Street in the Film Society of Lincoln Center: Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center amphitheater
results.name: Exploring the Intersection of Story & Play at Lincoln Center

results.description:
Join Nafisa Sharriff and the West African Dance Family for Free Classes every Monday and Wednesday evening from 6pm – 8pm at Countee Cullen/PS 194. located on 144th Street between Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglas Blvds in Harlem, NY. 

Summer Hours: 5pm – 7pm (July and August only).

Nafisa Sharriff is a Master Teacher and Choreographer of Traditional West African Folklore from the Old Malian Empire. She is the recipient of the 1996 Ethnic Dance Award and numerous Community Service commemorations. Throughout her illustrious career Nafisa performed with Stevie Wonder, Whitney Houston, Spike Lee, TC Carson, C&C Music Factory, The Chuck Davis Dance Company & The Kairaba West African Dance Company. Her television credits include performances on the Richard Pryor Show, Dance Black America & Positively Black.

results.description:
NOTE: This event is starting 15 minutes earlier: networking will begin at 5:45 p.m. and welcome remarks will start at 6:30 p.m.

Seal the deal. Drive the hard bargain. Turn a dispute into détente.

If you’d like tips and strategies on how to be a better negotiator, don’t miss this great event the evening of March 28 at the Feliciano School of Business (room 101), Montclair State. A panel of experts will explain how to hammer out a deal, whether it’s a business transaction, salary negotiation or resolution of a conflict.

Panelists will also discuss whether women need to negotiate differently than men. Should women use a gentler, softer approach—or play hardball in heels? Are there lower expectations when a woman is sitting at the negotiation table—and if so, is there a way to capitalize on that?

Panelists:
Mimi Feliciano, founder and CEO, FEM Real Estate
Fran Hauser, partner, Rothenberg Ventures
Rosaria Suriano, partner, Meyner and Landis
Moderator: Michele Ansbacher, vice president (retired), Prudential Financial

Event is presented by the Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship and the Women’s Center for Entrepreneurship Corp.

Event is co-sponsored by Residence Life.


Event is free and open to the public. Men are welcome and encouraged to attend.


Agenda:
5:45-6:30 p.m. Networking with pizza
6:30-6:45 p.m. Welcome and 30-second pitches from the audience
6:45-8:15 p.m. Panel discussion with audience Q&A

Directions and parking info: Park in the Red Hawk Deck on campus, exit the deck on Level 5 and proceed straight up the walkway (soccer field will be on your left) to the new Feliciano School of Business building. Campus map with directions.

Join the conversation on Twitter and Instagram: #MSUmeetup and @FelicianoCenter and @WCECNJ

Speaker bios:
Mimi Feliciano is founder and CEO of FEM Real Estate, a Real Estate Investment Company, based in Montville. FEM develops, owns and manages commercial real estate nationwide, and Mimi is often at the negotiating table, closing complex deals. Currently, Mimi is working on a redevelopment project in Long Branch which will feature 47 luxury beachfront condominiums. Mimi spent 12 years prior as the owner and CEO of Lincoln Park Healthcare, the largest nursing home complex in New Jersey. Mimi is a member of the advisory boards of the Feliciano School of Business and Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship. Read full bio.

Fran Hauser is a venture capital investor, digital media veteran, and an advocate for women and kids. She is passionate about connecting people and inspiring change. An active investor, Hauser is a partner at Rothenberg Ventures ("RV"). Through her work at RV and as an angel investor, she has actively supported dozens of innovative companies including ZADY, LevoLeague, Hullabalu, Bustle and HelloGiggles and has invested in some of the most promising companies in digital media and e-commerce. Before diving into the world of venture capital, Hauser spent 15 years in the digital media space, most recently as the President of Digital for Time Inc.’s Style and Entertainment Group (SEG).  In that role, Hauser oversaw PEOPLE.com, the most visited site in the publishing industry; EW.com, InStyle.com and Essence.com. Read full bio.

Rosaria Suriano, a partner at Meyner and Landis, is an experienced litigation attorney representing large and mid-sized companies in business litigation, contract disputes, real estate transactions and construction litigation. She brings to her clients the wisdom and knowledge of over 24 years of trial and appellate court experience in both state and federal courts. She has worked for several of the state’s largest and most prominent law firms. She recently headed the commercial litigation department of a business boutique law firm. She has successfully handled complex contract and business matters, including partnership/shareholder disputes, trade secret and restrictive covenant litigation, and domain name disputes. Read full bio.

Michele Ansbacher recently retired from Prudential Financial. Her role prior to retiring was the Vice President of the Eastern Territory in Agency Distribution, Prudential’s nationwide sales organization. She was responsible for the oversight of 14 agencies in the Eastern U.S. including Maine, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Jersey, New York and Eastern Pennsylvania. Michele, who began her Prudential career as a management intern, held a variety of positions at the company and found herself negotiating both internally and externally. A graduate of Montclair State, she is a member of the advisory board of the university’s Feliciano School of Business. Read full bio.
results.name: Playing Hardball in Heels: Learn the Art of Negotiation

results.description:
SIGN UP HERE

Event Description
Margaret Bourke White’s photograph of The Fort Peck Dam was on the first cover of Life Magazine.
Laura Gilpin worked as a turkey farmer so that she could afford to buy just one sheet of film at a time and then she drove alone for hours through rural New Mexico to expose that one sheet of film at just the right time of day.
As early as 1843 Botanist, Anna Atkins used cyanotypes to take photographs of dried algae for her book, British Algae Impressions, which was the first book ever published with photographic illustrations.
Women have been part of the photography industry since the beginning and during Women’s History month Adorama wants to celebrate women’s contributions to photography.
Join documentary photographer, Dorie Hagler, for a presentation celebrating the work of women photographers then and now.
results.name: History of Women’s Photography

Hasta pronto!

Beguinner level means: you are not able to speak without the help of the teacher, you just know really little common expresions. We will go thought the basics.

Intermediate level means: you can explain yourself with the help of the teacher, you can build up sentences but they are basic or you make mistakes on them. You have lacks of vocabulary and grammar.

Advanced level means: you are fluent in Spanish, you can explain yourself without a lof of problems. You know the vocabulary. Advanced students normally make gramatical mistakes when they talk and can forget some words, that is perfectly normal.

There is a world of gaming outside of the traditional Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk, etc. Whether you're looking for something new and different, or you're a seasoned gamer, you'll find a friendly and welcoming bunch of friends to game with.  Be adventurous , come learn some new games or play your favorites!

We begin gathering around 6:30 pm and are fully underway by 7pm.

Because the event takes place at a restaurant that serves alcohol, there are strict rules against gambling of any form.  Guests under 21 are welcome, as it is a restaurant. Since they are letting us use the space for free, they expect that we will order food and drink, so there are some rules:

1.  No outside food or drink, not even bottled water.

2. Please plan on ordering food and/or drinks.  Support the venue.

3. Tip the waitstaff generously.  15% is standard, but 20% is even better. We want them to love having us there, and in this case, money does buy you love.


4. If you plan on attending regularly, please consider a small contribution to cover The Tipsy Meeple's costs for using Meetup.

We bring some of our games, but feel free to bring your favorites, or learn one of ours! And don't be shy about learning new games, we are more than willing to teach a new player! Can't wait to see you there.

results.description:
Presented by NYC Data Science Academy students who are about to finish 12-week full time program. Apply April 2016 bootcamp Now. 


++++++++++++++++++++++++ 

During this event you will see some of the best Machine learning projects created by NYC Data Science Academy 12-week Data Science bootcamp students. 


You will also have an opportunity to meet our bootcamp students and find out more about what it is like to be a student at NYC Data Science Academy and gain an overview of the program. Join us for data wrangling tips, fun facts and in-depth discussions.

Event schedule:

6:30 pm - 7:00 pm Check in, mingle, enjoy food & drinks

7:00 pm - 8:30 pm Student presentation


8:30 pm - 9:00 pm Network and meet our students


====================


Project 1: Forest Cover Type Classification Study by Thomas Kolasa & Aravind Raja


Thomas and Aravind will present their research classifying forest cover types for data from Roosevelt National Forest in northern Colorado. The data consists of over forty categorical and continuous environmental and cartographic variables. With more than half a million observations, the data is apt for machine learning. They will present their findings with visualizations, logistic regressions, neural networks, tree based methods, and ensembling using R.



Project 2: Improving Home Depot Search Relevance by Amy Ma, Brett Amdur, Christopher Redino

Given only raw text as input, our goal is to predict the relevancy of products to search results at the Home Depot website. Our strategy is a little different from most other teams in this Kaggle competition, where we generated a work flow that starts from text cleaning, passes through feature engineering and ends with model selection and parameter tuning in attempt to stand out among thousands of competitors.

Project 3: Predicting Customer Satisfaction at Santander Bank from Anonymized Data by Anna Bohun, Thomas Boulenger, Adam Owens & Ashwin Swamy


As part of an ongoing Kaggle competition, NYCDSA Data Scientists tackle Santander Bank’s question of how to identify dissatisfied customers early in their relationship. Santander aims to take proactive steps to improve their customers' happiness, but faces a major roadblock in trying to make sense out of information that has been anonymized to protect customer privacy. This issue is common in retail today -- how can retailers cater to customers without knowing who they are?

The Data Scientists designed and engineered a data balancing neural network and compared it to popular gradient boosted machine algorithms. The data scientists will touch on the importance of feature engineering, dimensional reduction, and computational efficiency. The results provide interesting insights into the complications of neural network precision and the operational efficiency of gradient boosted machines.
results.name: Machine Learning project demo day

Visit us at Metis in New York City on Monday, March 28th at 6:30pm to see an Intro to Data Science presentation by Sergey Fogelson. Sergey is the instructor of the course and a consulting data scientist.

This is an Open House for Sergey's upcoming 6-week, evening Introduction to Data Science course, which starts on April 19th and will be held on Tuesday and Thursday evenings from 6:30 - 9:30pm through May 26th . Please RSVP if you would like to learn more about the course structure and outcomes, and to see Sergey illustrate the "data science cycle."

Pizza and drinks will be served.

6:30 - 7:00 Register, Mingle, Eat & Drink 
7:00 - 7:30 Instructor Sergey Fogelson presents 
7:30 - 8:00 Chat with Sergey, attendees, Metis staff and enjoy more food & drink 

Sergey Fogelson 
Metis Intro to Data Science Instructor 
Director of Data Science, airisData

Sergey Fogelson is a data science consultant currently working in the financial industry. He began his career as an academic at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire, where he researched the neural bases of visual category learning and obtained his Ph.D. in Cognitive Neuroscience. After leaving academia, Sergey got into the rapidly growing startup scene in the NYC metro area, where he has worked as a data scientist in alternative energy analytics, digital advertising, and cybersecurity. He is heavily involved in the NYC-area teaching community and has taught courses at various bootcamps, as well as been a volunteer teacher in computer science through TEALSK12. When Sergey is not working or teaching, he is probably hiking. (He thru-hiked the Appalachian trail before graduate school).

Connect with us before the event! @thisismetis
results.name: Open House: Introduction to Data Science Evening Course

Game description: 

Teams are 4 V 4, no goalies, no gender requirements (but we'd like at least 1 female player per team). Games will be played on a 1st goal rotation basis or 15 minutes time limit. The team that scores first stays on  the field. But if your team remains on the field after scoring 3 goals, we'll split the team up so that everyone has a fair chance to have a great game.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! 

VERY IMPORTANT: 

- NO FOULS

- NO SIDE TACKLING

- NO PUSHING

- NO TELLING OFF

* ZERO TOLERANCE*


By minimizing physical contact, we minimize injuries and violence.


         “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.


Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!

We encourage competitive, but safe play. 

We reserve the right to ask anyone to leave who has exhibited any behavior that could be construed as violent, offensive, or dangerous. 

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game. 


Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board, 10 PM the night before to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

West End Presbyterian Church

165 West 105th Street, New York, NY

Near the lines: 1, 2, 3, B, and C trains.

AS YOU COME IN, TAKE THE STAIRS ON YOUR LEFT AND WALK TO THE 4TH FLOOR.

Call me if you can’t find us - (917)[masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you: 
A positive attitude, pair of sneakers or INDOOR shoes (ONLY), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee: 
You will be asked to pay $9.25 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.25 dollars is used to pay for: permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, Goals, soccer balls etc.

Refund Policy:


* The Meetup is cancelled

* You can cancel at least 2 day(s) before the Meetup


Very IMPORTANT Due to the location where we will be playing:

We expect everyone to respect the facilities and act accordingly.

Anyone who is asked to leave will not be refunded and WILL be permanently banned from the group

After the game we can go for a quick drink at:

                                            TAP a KEG

It was so popular the first time we are going to do it again. The location will depend on how many RSVPs this event gets this time. We reached our limit last time.

The premise of this meetup event is simple:

Someone poses a problem faced by their small business (or a friend's small business) and the group discusses ideas on how to solve the problem.

Rather than discuss abstract problems and solutions, we discuss the specific problems raised by the meetup's participants.

Some examples:

Your business plan estimated that you would have 100 new customers by your third month in business, but you only have 10.

A client sues you in court and your lawyer wants to charge you more to fight the case than the client is suing you for.

Clients refuse to pay your invoices and you desperately need the money.

So please join us if you are interested in sharing your knowledge and experience with other small business owners. Or join us if you have a crisis and would like to tap the brain trust of the group to solve it.
results.name: Small Business Problem Solving Think Tank

From Development to Market: The Safety Dictates of the Food and Drug Administration with medical writer and consultant Clifton Hotvedt

THE PROCESS BY WHICH THE FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION (FDA) GIVES APPROVAL FOR MARKETING

Informal discussion with medical writer and consultant Clifton Hotvedt.  Learn about the history and current process for approving drugs by the FDA – including the recent changes to its review process so that drugs may be moved to market as expeditiously as possible.

Hovedt is Consultant and past Global Director of Medical and Scientific Affairs for the Ketchum public relations firm and senior medical writer at Ives Laboratories, a Pfizer Legacy Company.

To be an informed citizen, one should have a grasp of how scientists work. We need to be able to spot junk science or pseudo science so that when something is presented as “scientific,” we’ll be able to respond knowlegeably. At each session, a scientist, engineer, doctor or science writer will tell us about his/her area of expertise and will answer our questions and discuss aspects of interest. 

 Wine and cheese will be served.


Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

results.description:
This course will teach you how to use NPM for your projects and publish packages for others to use in their projects.

NPM is not just for Node developers - it has become the default package manager for front end JavaScript developers as well. This course will take you from knowing nothing about NPM to being an expert in using NPM to manage the dependencies for your project. Additionally, you will learn how to publish packages for other developers to use in their own projects, how to keep those packages updated, and how to coordinate them with your github repository.

About the Author: Joe Eames began his love of programming on an Apple III in BASIC. Although his preferred language is JavaScript, he has worked professionally with just about every major Microsoft language. He is currently a consultant and full time author for Pluralsight. Joe has always had a strong interest in education, and has worked both full and part time as a technical teacher for over ten years. He is a frequent blogger and speaker, organizer of ng-conf, the AngularJS conference (www.ng-conf.org), and a panelist on the JavaScript Jabber podcast (http://javascriptjabber.com/)
results.name: NPM Playbook Week 1 of 1

Join us to learn more about an incredible civic technology, SQUID, which stands for Street Quality Identification Device. It is a low-cost, scalable method of performing citywide street quality measurements. Our speaker, Varun Adibhatla, will also discuss ARGO Lab's civic data science framework i.e. integrating device, data and decision-making towards urban tech solutions.

Varun Adibhatla [@vr00n] is a founding member at ARGO Labs, a civic data science organization that rapidly prototypes around device, data and decision-making towards delivering new solutions for old city problems. ARGO's Team built Street Quality Identification Device or SQUID - a low-cost sensor platform that when mounted on city vehicles can perform citywide street surveys by integrating accelerometer data with images and empowers end users to prioritize street repairs and work towards preventative maintenance by using a complete dataset as opposed to 311/citizen reported data. With over $1.6 billion projected over 10 yrs in spending on street surfacing, Varun will demonstrate how SQUID is a scalable and sustainable way for NYC and other cities to make more informed and optimize decisions around street resurfacing. SQUID is a grant recipient of the Knight foundation's 2015 Prototyping Fund and was also a finalist at the 2015 NYC BIG APPS, Connected Cities category.

Varun is a recent graduate of NYU CUSP's Master's program in Urban Informatics. He also has a master's degree in Information Sciences from Penn State studying Human Computer Interaction.
results.name: SQUID! - The civic technology, not the cephalopod

results.description:
Join us at MakerBar on Saturday March 7th for an intensive three hour program to dive deep into the world of 3D printing technology and Additive Manufacturing. We will cover all the basics and need-to-know information for beginners, hobbyists, and people with a professional interest who are interested in learning facts, and debunking myths, regarding the basics of 3D printing and additive manufacturing. 

This will be a 3 hour class with time for Q and A to ask all your 3D printing questions, as well as a concise demonstration of the process. The main topics on the agenda are: 

Part I: Introduction to FDM / FFF Printing, the most common type We will explain how the mechanics of a basic 3D printer functions to create objects from bits of data. 

Part 2: 3D Printing Materials
We discuss material types, material properties, and address common material properties. We will pass around different material samples, and talk about the differences.

Part 3: Designing for 3D Printers
We'll spend some time talking about support structures, rafts, dissolving supports like HIPS, and PVA, and talk about Shapeways and 3D Hubs, and how to get your stuff printed. We will also discuss 3D print finishing techniques and tools such as using files, sandpaper, and chemical finishing. Assembly techniques will also be overviewed including using chemical welding, friction welding, snap fits, screws and rivets, and augmenting prints with metal inserts.

Part 4: 3D Printing Communities, Resources, Service Bureaus, and Advanced Topics We will discuss online sites like Thingiverse, GrabCad, and 123D, and downloading and uploading models and other parts. We will also talk about getting models made and trouble shooting, along with some pitfalls of 3D Printing to avoid. 

Also each signup comes with a voucher for one free 3D print at MakerBar on any open night! (Subject to printer availability which is first come first serve). 

About your instructors: 

Tom Beattie is a graphic designer turned 3D designer and entrepreneur who learned from the ground up how to use 3D modeling and printing to bring his ideas to life. 

Michael Lowry is a Mechanical and Mechatronics engineer who has been using many 3D printing technologies in the medical research field at New York University and is an expert in motion and control systems. 

Together, they have prepared a lot of valuable content that can help you enter the field of 3D printing armed with more knowledge to save you from costly mistakes up front, help you understand the limitations and challenges as well as the incredible capabilities of various current 3D printing technologies, and point you to where you can further your knowledge and put your ideas to the test and keep adding to your knowledge. 

Price: $39 
MakerBar Members: Free

All proceeds from the class go back to support MakerBar which is a registered 501(c)3 educational not for profit charity. Your support helps keep us open for the community so we can offer a place to meet, build, and learn together, and keep our equipment--including our 3D printers-- running, and available to the community.

[PLEASE NOTE: All minors must be accompanied by parent and or guardian.] 

MakerBar is a 501(c)3 NJ Non-Profit Organization.. All donations are tax deductible.....consider donating today...Help keep the H@ck3ry alive! 

Interested in membership? Speak to one of our members about the many benefits of membership as well as the outstanding community that is Hoboken's MakerBar. Hudson County's one and only Hackerspace.

http://www.makerbar.com

twitter: @MakerBar

facebook: http://www.facebook.com/TheMakerBar

This is a free group for anyone who enjoys playing board games and would like to make new friends while doing so. No previous knowledge of board games is necessary. We're happy to help newcomers along with how to play, as well as how to plan strategies to win the games.  

Our event is every Monday night at Dave & Buster's in Westbury Long Island from 6:30pm to 10:30pm.  You can leave prior to 10:30pm if you want, also please note that Dave & Buster's closes at Midnight for those who want to stay later. 

Most people arrive at 6:30pm.  We use the first 30 minutes to talk, order food/drinks, and pick out games while we wait for any people that are a little late.  Promptly at 7pm we split into groups and play our games that typically take 2 hours to play.  So, if you arrive after 7pm there is a good chance that you will not be able to get into a game and can watch us play if you'd like.  At the end of the night we play a couple of additional shorter games that you can get into.

This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's (We are located 1 room over from the pool tables).  This group meets at the dining tables directly in front of the bowling lanes. There is no cover charge to enter Dave & Buster's and plenty of parking is available. Also, there is no fee to join this meetup group. All that management at Dave & Buster's asks is that each person purchase $5 off their menu (it can be 1 appetizer, or 1 dessert, or a few sodas, basically whatever you choose).  

Plenty of board games will be present at this event, but feel free to bring some of your favorites. Some of the games that we play are Kingsburg, Stone Age, Lords of Waterdeep, Istanbul, Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Love Letter Batman, Splendor, Pirate's Cove, Five Tribes, Castles of Burgundy, and more.  

Here is a list of the board games I own on the BGG website: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/MarkNY8?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Here is a list of Co-Host Kenny's games on BGG: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/kenk1982?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Looking forward to meeting you. 

Mark

Not yet a member? Learn how to become an AS member or a YPA member to access this event.

Visionary Mexican composer and conductor Carlos Chávez polarized audiences and critics in Mexico with his cross-pollination of traditional music from his home country and 20th-century music. In the late 1920s, he was one of the founding members of the Pan-American Association of Composers (PAAC) in New York, working closely with Henry Cowell and Edgar Varèse. Chávez, alongside Cuban avant-gardists Amadeo Roldán and Alejandro García Caturla, were the composers whose music was most often performed at the PAAC concerts, and all embraced a firm desire to combine elements from their countries' popular music with traditional concert forms and instruments, creating uniquely American music. This program presents pieces that appeared—frequently as world premieres—in International Composers' Guild and PAAC concerts.

Program

Amadeo Roldán (1900–1939) Ritmica no. 1 (1930) Carlos Chávez (1899–1978)

Tres exágonos 

(1923) C. Chávez Otros tres exágonos (1924)

Performers

The City of Tomorrow wind quintet Sarah Brailey soprano Stephanie Griffin viola Alexandre Moutouzkine piano

This event is part of the "Modernismo Rumbero" series.

http://www.as-coa.org/events/concert-modernismo-rumbero

https://introduction-to-front-end-development-march.eventbrite.com

Course Description

Fullstack Academy's Introduction to Front-End Development is an in-depth 10 week course covering the fundamentals of front-end web development. Taught by experienced Fullstack Academy Instructors, the class will dive deep into client-side development, covering everything from HTML5, CSS3, Intermediate JavaScript, jQuery, Responsive Design, MVC Frameworks, and more. Modelled after Fullstack Academy's renowned Software Engineering Immersive, the Introduction to Front-End course is structured in a lecture-workshop format, with each concept taught solidified through practical application.

Who is this Course For?

Introduction to Front-End Development is designed for beginner programmers. It's well suited for:

Marketers
Product/Project Managers
Designers
Other Professionals seeking to add a technical skill-set to their resume
Non-Technical Entrepreneurs
Beginners getting started on the path to becoming a software developer
Anyone interested in breaking into the world of coding Course Dates & Times

Course Dates: March 28, 2016 - June 1, 2016 (10 Weeks)

Schedule: Mon & Wed Evenings | 6:45PM – 9:45PM

What is the Curriculum?

Introduction to Front-End Development covers a wide array of development concepts, technologies, and tools. Building a functional, responsive front-end involves many components, so the curriculum spans several areas over the course of 10 intense weeks. Topics include:

HTML5
CSS3
JavaScript Fundamentals
JavaScript Practical Components
Document Object Model (DOM)
Bootstrap
jQuery
Object Oriented Programming (OOP)
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
Data Interchange Formats (JSON & AJAX)
Back-End Integration
Introduction to Model-View-Controller Architectural Patterns (MVC) What is the Tuition?

Tuition for this course is $3,650. An initial deposit of $450 is required to reserve your spot in the course. The remainder of the tuition is paid on the first day of class.

What do I need to bring?

Students must bring a functioning laptop to class. Macs are preferred, however Windows machines are acceptable. You will also need to complete roughly 10 hours of pre-work before the first day of class.

Where can I find more details?

More details on Fullstack Academy and the Introduction to Front-End Development course can be found here: http://www.fullstackacademy.com/part-time/front-end-development

results.description:
Last month, we had a great discussion, lead by Stuart, on Dealing with Difficult People. This month, let's explore another challenging topic - Stress.

According to Psychology Today, "stress is simply a reaction to a stimulus that disturbs our physical or mental equilibrium. In other words, it's an omnipresent part of life." I'd like to add to that to say that the stimulus can be a physical threat that triggers an immediate “fight-or-flight” response, or it can be more chronic and long-term, such as in the case of illness, or emotional upset, including separation from or loss of a loved one(s), job loss, financial difficulties, or even day to day survival. Some types of stress, such short-term "butterflies" before a job interview or exam can be positive and aid performance. But long-term chronic activation of the internal stress response can have detrimental effects on health. The good news is, although you may not be able to eradicate all of the stressors in your life, it is possible to alter your reaction to them and maintain your "equilibrium."

Let's explore these questions:

1. How do you personally define "stress?"

2. Why do we feel it?

3. When is it positive/negative?

4. Why do some people seem more resistant to stress than others?

5. What can we do about it?

Here are a couple articles on stress:


https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/fulfillment-any-age/201303/the-six-best-kept-secrets-about-stress


http://www.apa.org/helpcenter/stress.aspx

Here are two more that Paul found:

https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/01/160121121818.htm


https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/02/160204111636.htms

Looking forward to seeing everyone. It's sure to be a great discussion!
results.name: Dinner and Discussion on... Stress
